item.title: Thank you for all of the resources here!
item.dc:creator: TheresaGorman
item.content:encoded: Thank you for all of the resources here! I'm just starting out learning about how to use corpora. Have you heard about this new book: Discovering English with Sketch Engine by James Thomas? It looks interesting: http://versatile.pub/tiki-index.php?page=DESKE [embed]http://versatile.pub/tiki-index.php?page=DESKE[/embed]
item.excerpt:encoded: Thank you for all of the resources here!

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Hi Theresa Great thank you, glad to hear you find this community useful always nice to hear from members :) Yes James gave an interview about book here https://eflnotes.wordpress.com/2015/06/14/discovering-english-with-sketchengine-james-thomas-interview/ hoping to review it when I can so stayed tuned
James also Spoke at Iatefl, and motivated me to use SkeLL. My students 'undergraduates in Verona' love it :-)
folks interested can see how Sharon used SKELL with her class here - https://hartlelearning.wordpress.com/2015/04/30/post-manchester-iatefl-reflections/

Thnx for sharing this,
All the best, Sharon
Inviato da iPad
a pleasure Sharon, hope u r managing to keep cool in the heat

item.title: Lancaster University is going to launch an online course on #corpus #linguistics starting in January 2014 -...
item.dc:creator: MuraNava
item.content:encoded: Lancaster  University is going to launch an online course on #corpus #linguistics starting in January 2014 - https://www.futurelearn.com/courses/corpus-linguistics. It is aimed at researchers so not sure if #language #teachers   will be interested but as it's free no harm in checking it out when it does launch. :) In the meantime there is already a great online course (aimed at #translators ); units 1 and 2 are great primers for those new to corpora whilst the other units are very interesting for further study. e.g. unit on regular expressions. You can use it as a guest or register for a free account http://parles.upf.edu/llocs/moodle/course/view.php?id=311 [embed]http://parles.upf.edu/llocs/moodle/course/view.php?id=311[/embed]
item.excerpt:encoded: Lancaster University is going to launch an online course on #corpus #linguistics starting in January 2014 -...

item.title: Reading Concordances by John Sinclair is a great tutorial book -...
item.dc:creator: MuraNava
item.content:encoded: Reading Concordances by John Sinclair is a great tutorial book - http://mssesteachers.wikispaces.com/file/view/Reading_Concordances--An_Introduction+(4).pdf. It shows you in detail how to go about working with concordances. Highly worth spending time on I would say. The text files of the examples used in the book can be found in this link http://www.twc.it/rc/readings.htm [embed]http://mssesteachers.wikispaces.com/file/view/Reading_Concordances--An_Introduction+(4).pdf[/embed]
item.excerpt:encoded: Reading Concordances by John Sinclair is a great tutorial book -...

your welcome, that book really is essential imo
glad u got it sorted :) i actually got a copy of the book first from the corpus4u chinese forum, another great resource to check once in while.
hi you can just use antconc?

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
found that one can use the BAWE as a learner corpus, using CQL search you need to use this command: within so i searched for uses of the word important in French users like thus: [lemma="important"] within i got 117 results out of which i spotted 5 "incorrect" uses of important: ------------------------------ a) Also, Kathmandu being known as the most important gambling city of the Indian subcontinent b) entry in Nepal are low, which creates an important threat of new entrants.

4.2 Threat of c) significant (59.2%). There seem to be an important British demand for tourism, since in 2002 d) or Caribbean immigrants who actually form important communities in the capital. I thought that e) Nepalese technological environment present important deficiencies. Although it has a lot of ----------------------------- have been trying to find out what other first languages are represented but have only got refs to german and french, anyone know any more about this?
Aw Mulalee - this looks brill .. an I don't have the time to look properly .... I'll definitely be back ... hope I don't loose it LOL

hey elizabeth
if u explore it more do report back to this community :)

so apparently the BAWE (ht Michael Harrison for alerting me to updated BAWE site which has an excel sheet of metadata - http://www.coventry.ac.uk/Global/05%20Research%20section%20assets/Research/British%20Academic%20Written%20English%20Corpus%20(BAWE)/BAWE%20table%202%20April%202012.xls) includes the following languages (with count): Arabic (16) Bengali (5) Bulgarian (7) Cantonese (66) Mandarin (26) Chinese Unspecified (153) Czech (5) Dutch (13) English (1953) Finnish (15) French (60) German (57) Greek (46) Gujarati (10) Hindi (33) Hungarian (3) Igbo (3) Italian (12) Japanese (40) Korean (11) Malay (23) Maldivian (5) Mongolian (2) Norwegian (12) Panjabi (1) Persian (11) Polish (34) Portuguese (24) Pulaar  (5) Romani (5) Serbian (1) Sinhala (22) Slovak (10) Slovenian (5) Spanish (17) Swahili (5) Swedish (15) Tamil (8) Thai (9) Turkish (6) Urdu (5) Welsh (3)

item.title: +NewSchool #webinar titled #Corpus Confidence by Amy Tate & Emilia Siravo.
item.dc:creator: MuraNava
item.content:encoded: +NewSchool #webinar titled #Corpus Confidence by Amy Tate & Emilia Siravo. Covers #WordandPhrase , #JusttheWord and Google #Ngram They did a survey of 50 ESL teachers (mostly US and Europe) on knowledge and use of corpus based tools. 22% reported not hearing about corpus based tools this compares with nearly 80% in 2001/2002 of secondary school English teachers (total 248 respondents) in Germany not knowing about corpus linguistics. So some progress over 12 years or so :) Another finding from the talk is that 66% are NOT using corpus based tools in their teaching, this compares with  a survey of 600 teachers (mainly university level) in 2012 where 75% WERE using corpus tools in one way or another. A major reason for no use was lack of time which was also found in the 2012 university based teachers survey. Also seems Scott Thornbury is going to do a course this summer titled Corpora for language teaching. Any more info on this Scott? Anyway worthwhile checking the video :) [embed]https://newschool.adobeconnect.com/_a1107314744/p11z2tc19zj/?launcher=false&fcsContent=true&pbMode=normal[/embed]
item.excerpt:encoded: +NewSchool #webinar titled #Corpus Confidence by Amy Tate & Emilia Siravo.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Yes, Mura-- it's a one-credit online course as part of the MA TESOL but may be taken independently (at some cost, I have to say). For real or false beginners!
ah okay thanks for info

item.title: This is part 3 of 3 videos by the #Virtual #Linguistics #Campus
item.dc:creator: MuraNava
item.content:encoded: This is part 3 of  3 videos by the #Virtual #Linguistics #Campus . They use the Lancaster BNCWeb which you need to register as described in video 1. Video 3 was very useful for me as I found out how to search for pre-fixes and suffixes for verbs i.e. use the VVI part of speech tag - infinitive form of verb. You can try this in COCA-BYU by using the examples from the video of looking at verb forms with en as a prefix and as a suffix, i.e.: en*.[v?i*] - http://corpus.byu.edu/bnc/?c=bnc&q=33478109 *en.[v?i*] - http://corpus.byu.edu/bnc/?c=bnc&q=33478118 h/t i_narrator @i_narrator  for video 2 on BNC frequency search [embed]http://youtu.be/hyeCAGzmrVY[/embed]
item.excerpt:encoded: This is part 3 of 3 videos by the #Virtual #Linguistics #Campus

item.title: A new self-study "course" on Corpus Linguistics by Monika Bednarek.
item.dc:creator: MuraNava
item.content:encoded: A new self-study "course" on Corpus Linguistics by Monika Bednarek. I put the course in inverted commas since this flows more like a collection of resources and in fact was orignally "an online information/resource pack on corpus linguistics". Hence a number of links are external which can get annoying when you click them and you need to wait for a new window to open, this should be labelled in the table of contents as such. The section on debates has the Chomsky and CL talking point which needs updating in the sense that it is highly debatable whether Chomsky really did "discredit corpus linguistics". However there are some interesting resources here for example a pdf of why people love corpora [http://www.cambridge.org/elt/resources/appliedlinguistics/corpus/CorpusSurvey.pdf. Finally as I had only a very cursory look I may be being too critical! :) h/t HelenCaple ‏@Medlec [embed]http://www.monikabednarek.com/7.html[/embed]
item.excerpt:encoded: A new self-study "course" on Corpus Linguistics by Monika Bednarek.

item.title: How can I use corpora to improve my academic writing in English?
item.dc:creator: MuraNava
item.content:encoded: How can I use corpora to improve my academic writing in English? Quick, straightforward intro to using corpora to help with academic writing. For a more comprehensive take check member Monika Sobejko's post Teaching writing with the aid of COCA [https://eflnotes.wordpress.com/2013/10/02/teaching-writing-with-the-aid-of-coca-guest-post-by-monika-sobejko/] [embed]http://scriptor.sprakverkstaden.uu.se/en/how-can-i-use-corpora-to-improve-my-academic-writing-in-english/[/embed]
item.excerpt:encoded: How can I use corpora to improve my academic writing in English?

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Nice! Thanks for sharing this Mura Nava! This is my current research focus for my Ph.D.
hi Peter how's the Ph.D going?
Mura Nava​ Thanks for asking. Oh it is going. I just finished my coursework phase so now I have to craft my dissertation proposal. Lots of reading and thinking at this stage.

item.title: C is for COCA
item.dc:creator: MuraNava
item.content:encoded: C is for COCA Scott Thornbury updates his COCA tutorial, nice [embed]https://youtu.be/pL61K2cELQg[/embed]
item.excerpt:encoded: C is for COCA

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Nice simple interface. Much more friendly to researchers and teachers alike.
C is for concordance.
C is for corpus.

item.title: COCA: Advanced Collocate Searches
item.dc:creator: LinguaF
item.content:encoded:
COCA: Advanced Collocate Searches
[embed]https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=L0ikCzl6SJk[/embed]
item.excerpt:encoded: COCA: Advanced Collocate Searches

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: it was only recently that i appreciated the importance of min frequency/relevance box from reading a blog post on collocates of feminist(s) - http://linguisticpulse.com/2014/08/26/militant-radical-man-hating-how-our-public-discourse-describes-feminists before i was happy to use default settings now i will try to use different minimums and a more careful reading of sample concordances!

Thanks for sharing this interesting article.
Having experimented with different options for “feminist.[n]” in COCA, I've discovered other rather extreme examples of adjectives like “queer”, “Marxist” and “socialist”, which occur within 4 words to the left or to the right of “feminist”.
The arguably more positive view of feminism has been reflected by adjectives like “strong” and “progressive”. However, the number of more positive adjectives is rather limited.
I’ll surely keep testing advanced collocate searches based on using the Parts of Speech tags, limitations and comparisons.
Thanks for those findings. Glad u enjoyed the article that blog is always worth checking. FYI to play around with gender u could have a go at http://bncgender.englishup.me
Absolutely! Thanks, Mura!

item.title: Can anyone help?
item.dc:creator: AmyAishaBrown
item.content:encoded: Can anyone help? I'm looking for some software that can calculate LL statistics with just frequency lists rather than whole corpora.
item.excerpt:encoded: Can anyone help?

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Cant help u on that,but I can suggest a place to put the question http://linguistforum.com/computational-linguistics/
Will try there, too. Thanks
have you tried #lancaster calculator? http://ucrel.lancs.ac.uk/llwizard.html

Hi Mura, Yes, I have looked at that. But I need to do it for one corpus versus another, not just one or two words. There is a spreadsheet on that page that would do the trick. The problem is that a large corpus is too big to fit into a spreadsheet.
Think I might have to put my shaky programming skills to work!
ah right, apparently wordsmith tools can do this http://www.lexically.net/downloads/version5/HTML/index.html?wordlist_overview.htm
or use excel 2010 onward as the row limit is bigger http://office.microsoft.com/en-001/excel-help/excel-specifications-and-limits-HP010342495.aspx
Still not big enough unfortunately. I have a 7 million word corpus.
so how many lines is your wordlist?

In the end I managed with R (using code from Stefan Th. Gries). However, I was an idiot. Just because my corpus is big, doesn't mean my word list is, does it? I could have just used the Excel sheet. Anyway, thanks for trying :)
great :) would be interested in the code you used? am sure this would be easier than copying/pasting many lines of a wordlist in excel!

well, I'm updating it very often so you can find tools that have just been launched..of course feel free to contribute :)

item.title: Hi, could anybody please recommend a good free speech recognition software?
item.dc:creator: RicardoNausa
item.content:encoded: Hi, could anybody please recommend a good free speech recognition software? I need it to transcribe my students' academic presentations.
item.excerpt:encoded: Hi, could anybody please recommend a good free speech recognition software?

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: hi Ricardo that's interesting you want to use speech recognition software as a way to speed up the transcription process? though you would have to train the software each time for a each student? best best for free is for linux systems e.g. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Speech_recognition_software_for_Linux and there is the general list http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_speech_recognition_software good luck

Hi Mura,
Thanks a lot for your reply. I am going to transcribe oral presentations given by my Colombian PhD level students in a EAP program. The purpose of getting the software has to do with my not being so good at typing. My advisor recommended getting the software for me to hear my students' presentations, repeat what they said, and get it transcribed.
I have not gotten anything yet, so I decided to do the typing. I am going to check the list that you suggested.
Thanks a lot for it.
Ricardo
okay good luck! i think currently there is no way to avoid doing it manually unfortunately.

item.title: I chanced upon a tool called #DeepDict recently http://gramtrans.com/deepdict/.
item.dc:creator: MuraNava
item.content:encoded: I chanced upon a tool called #DeepDict recently http://gramtrans.com/deepdict/. The screenshot is the result of looking up the #noun image. It shows you common ways that this word is used (a bit like the #WordSketch feature in #SketchEngine ). Unfortunately a free account only gives you 10 lookups a day. For 6 months use it wants to charge 21 Euros. It uses something called a constraint grammar to parse its #corpora ; not sure how this differs from the way WordSketch works which uses #POS tagging. (so far read that #constraint   #grammars are highly accurate and uses dependency networks?) Anyway a nice tool to explore, even if only 10 times a day :) update - Just found out free access is limited to 2 weeks! Bugger.
item.excerpt:encoded: I chanced upon a tool called #DeepDict recently http://gramtrans.com/deepdict/.

item.title: A collection of #corpora covering 230 languages! http://corpora.informatik.uni-leipzig.de/
item.dc:creator: MuraNava
item.content:encoded: A collection of #corpora covering 230 languages! http://corpora.informatik.uni-leipzig.de/ What is also interesting is information on co-occurrences, that is words occurring within the same sentence, in addition to words to the left and right of the search word. Furthermore there is a #visualization of the co-occurrences, see screenshot for the search term image, which clearly shows two groupings or clusters in use of the word. The corpora are web based so one can look up contemporary terms. You can also download the corpora and the #corpus viewer for offline use (windows program).
item.excerpt:encoded: A collection of #corpora covering 230 languages! http://corpora.informatik.uni-leipzig.de/

item.title: Looking for #authentic audio with pauses, hesitations, ums and errs? (e.g.
item.dc:creator: MuraNava
item.content:encoded: Looking for #authentic audio with pauses, hesitations, ums and errs?  (e.g. read this rationale http://eltmaterialswriter.com/2013/12/03/a-request-for-more-umms-errs-and-what-i-mean-to-say-is/). Want to help improve the #Lancaster interface to the #BNC audio #corpus ? Sign up here http://bncweb.lancs.ac.uk/bncwebSignup. If you don't get your automatic email authorization contact Sebastian Hoffman hoffmann at uni-trier dot de. Once signed up head on over to http://bncweb.lancs.ac.uk. The 1st screenhot shows a keyword analysis comparing spoken BNC to whole BNC (spoken+written). Check those ers and erms :) The second screenshot shows an example of searching for the word contract. The transcription is in pink at the top, then you see audio player and below the audio player is where you can give feedback on how aligned the audio is with the transcript.
item.excerpt:encoded: Looking for #authentic audio with pauses, hesitations, ums and errs? (e.g.

item.title: I was watching a great #britishcouncil presentation on English as a Lingua Franca, #ELF (by Katy Simpson...
item.dc:creator: MuraNava
item.content:encoded: I was watching a great #britishcouncil presentation on English as a Lingua Franca, #ELF   (by Katy Simpson Davies & Laura Patsko ) and in part 4 of the talk called Exploiting authentic materials, Laura Patsko  recommends two online resources for recordings of non-native speakers - Speech Accent Archive and International Dialects of English Archive. Another resource one can use are the 23 recordings available from the #VOICE (Vienna-Oxford International #Corpus of English) - http://www.univie.ac.at/voice/page/index.php. These recordings can be accessed from the audio tab at the top of the UI screen - see first blue circle in screenshot below. The 23 recordings are a sample of the total in the corpus, which covers 5 domains: ED stands for educational, LE for leisure, PB for professional business, PO for professional organization, and PR for professional research and science. And the following 10 speech events: con (conversation), int (interview), mtg (meeting), pan (panel), prc (press conference), qas (question-answer session), sed (seminar discussion), sve (service encounter), wgd (working group discussion), and wsd (workshop discussion). So in the screenshot we have a Professional Business recording of a meeting. The number 29 is a number assigned to this text. In the screenshot label 1 indicates the audio player which can be controlled by rwd, play, fwd, a or the blue indicator, b. Label 2 shows bookmarks you can make for parts that you are interested in. Label 3 shows information on speaker , in this case speaker 1 who has a first language of German. Label 4 shows where you can display the transcript in various modes in this case plain text. For ideas on how to use such a resource in ELF contexts see full the British Council presentation -http://englishagenda.britishcouncil.org/seminars/practical-ideas-teaching-pronunciation-and-listening-english-lingua-franca-elf-context and the blog site http://elfpron.wordpress.com
item.excerpt:encoded: I was watching a great #britishcouncil presentation on English as a Lingua Franca, #ELF (by Katy Simpson...

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: There is another ELF corpus which has 50 videos with transcripts and search functions, this is part of the Backbone Pedagogic Corpora. http://webapps.ael.uni-tuebingen.de/backbone-search/faces/search.jsp The 50 videos cover Spanish ELF, Turkish ELF, French ELF, Asian ELF, Polish ELF and German ELF. It is worth checking out for the other corpora available as well.

item.title: In an attempt to balance somewhat the bias towards English language #corpora and demonstrate corpus use in other...
item.dc:creator: MuraNava
item.content:encoded: In an attempt to balance somewhat the bias towards English language #corpora   and demonstrate corpus use in other modern foreign languages #MFL   I am listing here two examples using #chinese   and #french : 1. This is a parallel Chinese corpus that seems to be based on some reading texts rather than on a general reference corpus. If any members here who understand Chinese want to verify this? http://engres.ied.edu.hk/paraconc/ Seems a very useful teaching tool approach. 2. This is French audio corpora recorded from one town - Orleans. What is great about this is the way a dialogue transcript is highlighted as you play the audio. Another cool feature is that you can select types of dialogue e.g. meetings, telephone call etc as well as other attributes. http://eslo.tge-adonis.fr/index.php/pagecorpus/pageaccescorpus If members know of other language corpora do comment/share. [embed]http://www.parallelcorpus.com[/embed]
item.excerpt:encoded: In an attempt to balance somewhat the bias towards English language #corpora and demonstrate corpus use in other...

item.title: So I have been using Word Neighbors (http://wordneighbors.ust.hk) somewhat frequently recently.
item.dc:creator: MuraNava
item.content:encoded: So I have been using Word Neighbors (http://wordneighbors.ust.hk) somewhat frequently recently. I was caught out by one of its features so here is a top tip. Make sure to use both the Words view as well as the Pattern view, this is because the accuracy of the Pattern analysis is not 100%. I was demonstrating the use of dependent prepositions with the adjective irritated. In the Pattern view the Adjective + Prep pattern lists irritating to (unexpected!) as most common. However if you look at Verb + Prep pattern this lists irritated by (expected!) as most frequent. Simply switching view to Word view reveals this instantly. [embed]http://wordneighbors.ust.hk[/embed]
item.excerpt:encoded: So I have been using Word Neighbors (http://wordneighbors.ust.hk) somewhat frequently recently.

item.title: http://language.sakura.ne.jp/icnale/ Another openaccess learner corpus, yah!
item.dc:creator: MuraNava
item.content:encoded: http://language.sakura.ne.jp/icnale/ Another openaccess learner corpus, yah! the only other online one (of English learners) I know of is the EFCAMDAT corpus - http://corpus.mml.cam.ac.uk/efcamdat/). This time from East Asian learners but with Native speaker group included for comparative research, nice! H/T FaceBook CL group [embed]http://language.sakura.ne.jp/icnale[/embed]
item.excerpt:encoded: http://language.sakura.ne.jp/icnale/ Another openaccess learner corpus, yah!

item.title: Corpora for spelling
item.dc:creator: MuraNava
item.content:encoded: Corpora for spelling Lancaster University has put up a launch page for various #Corpus #Linguistics related #programs (http://corpora.lancs.ac.uk/). One of them which caught my eye is called DICER - Discovery and Investigation of Character Edit Rules, in other words a program to look at #spelling forms. (http://corpora.lancs.ac.uk/dicer/) They have an analysis of a set of learner corpora (which ones is not given) and the screenshot shows the summary for French native speakers. 1. Edit distance means how far (how many edits) from the standard spelling the variant (mistake) is so here for French speakers the variant is most commonly 1 edit away e.g. scientifice/scientific 2. Is whether the variant is at the start, second, middle, penultimate or end, here the middle position is most common e.g. continiously/continuously 3. Is whether the variant is a deletion, insertion or substitution, the most common here is substitution 4. so if we look here the most common substitution is a hypen (-) for a space (_) e.g. television-quiz/television_quiz Variants are also classed into three error types - FS, FM and GADJN. FS - all spelling errors (e.g. parcs/parks), FM - morphological errors (e.g.injustly/unjustly), GADJN - when a general rule of grammar is broken (e.g.Europeans/European). Not sure how this could be incorporated into a lesson as most spelling errors are not high on teachers’ priority lists (I could be wrong on this though). Still it is an interesting source of such information, the other native speakers available are German and Spanish. update: Paul Rayson ‏@perayson reports that they used parts of the ICLE corpus.
item.excerpt:encoded: Corpora for spelling

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Well, if you do need a spelling lesson... here is an  error generator in Java that takes into acount probability of mispelling and can be applied to a corpus.  I am not sure if it is just being lazy or a lot of work, or both, though.... https://dbappserv.cis.upenn.edu/spell/
neat cheers matt :)

item.title: Title
item.dc:creator: MuraNava
item.content:encoded: Wow, #corpusmooc keeps on giving, someone has justed posted a Tim Johns program (circa 1994) called Contexts (http://myweb.tiscali.co.uk/wordscape/contexts.zip) which helps learners with several language items using #concordance data as you can seen in the screenshot called Top Level Menu, these are - adjectives, adverbs, body parts, house and garden, nouns, prefixes, prepositions, suffixes, verbs. As I had been doing prefixes in class today I had a look at the prefixes file which is shown in the following screenshots. This is an amazing program, I wonder if turning it into a web version would be very difficult? H/T James Ronald and John Higgins from #corpusmooc
item.excerpt:encoded: Title

item.title: #videogrep.py is a script that has loads of potential for language learning -...
item.dc:creator: MuraNava
item.content:encoded: #videogrep.py is a script that has loads of potential for language learning - http://lav.io/2014/06/videogrep-automatic-supercuts-with-python/ H/t John Johnston
item.excerpt:encoded: #videogrep.py is a script that has loads of potential for language learning -...

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: so i have been playing around with #videogrep , and it works a treat. for example here is a cut of adjective-noun pairs using one #episode of the #bigbangtheory supercut bigbangS07E22 adj noun an obvious activity is to get students to identify the pairs videogrep also allows to search for hypernyms e.g. all food related vocabulary here is another cut of the word well (see comment) that can be used with this vocabulary prompt https://plus.google.com/104940199413423400545/posts/WMoZ7pBM8pv note that the POS tagger that videogrep uses does not seem as accurate as say the #TreeTagger parser that #TagAnt uses
This looks amazing. Looking forward to playing around with it.

hi chris do share anything here of your thoughts after playing with it
a graphical user interface would be good to encourage more teachers to try it
in class i think best way would be as a hook to something and maybe potential for stronger, enthusiastic students to use it themselves?
I tried getting this to work for several hours, but couldn't get Python (on Windows) to download the modules. Seems cool though.
hi i run it on OSX and so was straightforward, maybe you could try running a linux virtualbox to see if that would work?
I'll give that a try when I get some time

item.title: Building your own corpus - TagAnt
item.dc:creator: MuraNava
item.content:encoded: Building your own corpus - TagAnt Laurence Anthony  does it again bringing difficult to set up programs to the masses with a #tagger called #TagAnt (http://www.antlab.sci.waseda.ac.jp/software.html). This is based on TreeTagger (http://www.cis.uni-muenchen.de/~schmid/tools/TreeTagger/) which if you follow the link you will see how involved it is to setup! I ran TagAnt on my multimedia #corpus then used the tagged corpus in AntConc. Before working with a tagged corpus in AntConc make sure to check all the boxes in the Global Settings>Token Definitions as in Screenshot1. Also here is a link to list of all the tags that Treetagger uses: http://courses.washington.edu/hypertxt/csar-v02/penntable.html Then use the #Clusters tool in AntConc (gleaned from reading the Google groups for AntConc https://groups.google.com/forum/#!forum/antconc). For example Screenshot2 shows running a search for verb + noun(inspect Screenshot2 for exact search term). Note that I have set the cluster size to 2. This shows me that verb + support is quite common: add support adds support adding support include support including support bringing support drop support introduces support I did not notice this when using the non-tagged corpus although support was in the top 60 in the wordlist it would have taken me longer to discern interesting patterns. Happy Tagging! p.s. this is continuing my series of diy corpus I started on my blog which you can read here if so interested:http://eflnotes.wordpress.com/tag/build-your-own-corpus/.
item.excerpt:encoded: Building your own corpus - TagAnt

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Apple OSX users can use CasualTreeTagger casualtreetagger | casualconcj It takes under a minute to process files, and has some options to give summary stats e.g. word lists, bigrams of pos etc. However only seems to output in vertical file format with a second column of lemmas. edit there is an option under output to select horizontal tagging - ~_* English help document casualtreetagger | casualconc
There is now an OSX version of #TagAnt

item.title: Focus Foundation Corpus
item.dc:creator: MuraNava
item.content:encoded: Focus Foundation Corpus A #corpus based on #university #student #writing from 1st year to PhD level of dissertations, essays, figures (this is a cool inclusion) & lab reports from the following subjects : biology, business, chemistry, criminology, earth sciences, history, medicine, physics, sociology, sports. #eap   They seem to use % as a wildcard though no other info on search terms. Very neat that it is available to public. There is also a related blog http://durhamfocusproject.wordpress.com/ h/t Diane Nicholls  [embed]http://www.dur.ac.uk/foundation.focus/external[/embed]

item.title: Some #legal #corpora :
item.dc:creator: MuraNava
item.content:encoded: Some #legal #corpora : 1. The Bononia Legal Corpus [http://corpora.dslo.unibo.it/bolc_eng.html]   - Italian/English, the English subsection approx 59 million words 2. JRC-Acquis [https://ec.europa.eu/jrc/en/language-technologies/jrc-acquis] a multilingual comparable collection of legal texts in 22 different languages focusing on European legislation 3.CorTec [ http://comet.fflch.usp.br/cortec] a scientific-technical collection of texts comparing English and Brazilian Portuguese on commercial law 4.House of Lords Judgments (HOLJ) Extractive Summarisation Corpus [http://www.inf.ed.ac.uk/research/isdd/admin/package?view=1&id=84] is monolingual and includes judicial decisions from the House of Lords above taken from A corpus-based proposal for the grading of vocabulary teaching materials for the legal english class [ https://www.academia.edu/9024315/A_corpus-based_proposal_for_the_grading_of_vocabulary_teaching_materials_for_the_legal_English_class] h/t M.K ‏@usage_based [embed]http://corpora.dslo.unibo.it/bolc_eng.html[/embed]

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Dear, Mura! Thank you for this useful resource which I've just reshared with our English Language Community by Peter Bothe at https://plus.google.com/u/0/communities/116269728875136256237  You are always welcome to have a look at our community.! Kind regards Alena
hi Alena great to hear that, will check out your community :)

Mura Nava Hi, Mura! Thanks for that.  Actually, these are two communities. One is an English Language Community where we can post and the other one is the ENGLISHKLUB by Peter Bothe where, weekly,  we have an English Language hangout. We have some native English language speakers there too. We participate in such interesting activities as reading or playing a quiz game. To participate on a quiz game you need to subscribe to ENGLISHKLUB to get an event notification. Feel free to have a look at. You are always welcome!   Please, find the links here:  ENGLISHKLUB - https://plus.google.com/+EnglishklubBlogspots/posts  English Language Community - https://plus.google.com/communities/116269728875136256237  Peter Bothe, our moderator - https://plus.google.com/u/0/+PeterBothe/posts  Kind regards Alena :)
ok thanks for info :)
Mura Nava Hi, Mura! You are welcome! :)

item.title: A new ad-based version of #SKELL Sketch Engine for English Language Learners by Sketch Engine is out http://skell.
item.dc:creator: MuraNava
item.content:encoded: A new ad-based version of #SKELL Sketch Engine for English Language Learners by Sketch Engine  is out http://skell.sketchengine.co.uk/run.cgi/skell Came in handy immediately as an issue came up in a class last week with the difference between invoice and bill. I had searched in COCA BYU using the comparison function but did not remember to search by part of speech and so was only thinking of the words as nouns. So the explanation involved the difference between using invoice when related to financial things and bill when related to legislation. Not too convincing an explanation I felt. However SKELL shows up part of speech as an option automatically after searching, so was reminded that (via the similar words feature) invoice when used as a verb is very similar to bill used as a verb, doh! So reminding me of the potential confusion in the differences between the two words and an added explanation, to the one I mentioned using COCA BYU, that may well help students. Ah well at least something to show/tell the class next lesson. h/t KBarrs @corpusloanword · [embed]http://skell.sketchengine.co.uk/run.cgi/skell[/embed]
item.excerpt:encoded: A new ad-based version of #SKELL Sketch Engine for English Language Learners by Sketch Engine is out http://skell.

item.title: this is a nice version of #googlefight for a corpus of conferences and papers in natural language processing and...
item.dc:creator: MuraNava
item.content:encoded:
this is a nice version of #googlefight for a corpus of conferences and papers in natural language processing and computational linguistics
what is nice is that the results are linked to concordances and other features found in Sketch Engine
an approach like this where results are available in different levels of detail is a good approach to use with corpus based tools
i wonder if the #sketchengine team would consider such an approach with their other open corpora?
note even if looglefight graph shows 0 hits clicking on bar may take you to some concordances
also seems search word looks at lemmas so you will need to inspect concordances and further filter them in sketchengine if you are after word forms instead h/t CorporaList
[embed]http://looglefight.com/[/embed]
item.excerpt:encoded: this is a nice version of #googlefight for a corpus of conferences and papers in natural language processing and...

item.title: Type your own script (TYOS) aims to help research #scientists develop their writing in English (free registration).
item.dc:creator: MuraNava
item.content:encoded:
Type your own script (TYOS) aims to help research #scientists develop their writing in English (free registration).
There are 37 texts on letters of complaint, case reports, articles (biochemistry, dentistry, medicine, cognitive psychology, wine science) letters of request for positions, letters of submission, remarks as a reviewer, reply to answers, abstracts.
Each text has a set of annotatations categorised into: Verb forms Discourse linkers Useful expressions Interesting grammar points Vocabulary points Moves
As the texts were from a French context the annotations contain glosses in French.
Overall a nice resource but the website is clunky to use e.g. you need to click around a lot when looking at annotations.
[embed]http://tyos.org/[/embed]
item.excerpt:encoded: Type your own script (TYOS) aims to help research #scientists develop their writing in English (free registration).

item.title: CARE Concordancer [http://candle.cs.nthu.edu.tw/care/] for #Academic #wRitten #English , can search...

item.content:encoded: CARE Concordancer [http://candle.cs.nthu.edu.tw/care/] for #Academic #wRitten #English , can search abstracts and full text articles in Applied Linguistics and Computer Science. What is notable is one can do a search by rhetorical move, nice. And search results can be highlighted for word in the Academic Word List.
item.excerpt:encoded: CARE Concordancer [http://candle.cs.nthu.edu.tw/care/] for #Academic #wRitten #English , can search...

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Can you tell me how it works?

Hi Mura,
Been out of G+ a bit but this link has a lot of potential for those who research academic writing. The “moves“ section especially since you can compare the use of words (or phrases to?) in different sections of a journal article. For example comparing usage in the methods section with the conclusion. Probably ideal for learners in university if it is used for data-driven learning. Good stuff!
Liliana Wai hi as Peter suggests play around with the moves filter also this page and paper may help https://calico.org/html/article_721.pdf#page=13
Thank you a lot
Liliana Wai no worries :)

item.title: An Arabic #learner #corpus (free registration), the interface is very nice with a useful set of filters.
item.dc:creator: MuraNava
item.content:encoded:
An Arabic #learner #corpus (free registration), the interface is very nice with a useful set of filters.
A great feature is that you can download audio files as well as written texts from your searches.
Info from Corpora List: -------- Arabic Learner Corpus (ALC)ALC contains a collection of written essays and spoken recordings categorised under two topics: A vacation trip (narrative) and My study interest(discussion) by learners of Arabic in Saudi Arabia in 2012 and 2013. The corpus includes 282,732 words, 29,627 types, and 1,585 materials. It was produced by 942 students from 67 nationalities, and 66 different L1 backgrounds studying at pre-university and university levels. The average length of a text is 178 words. --------
[embed]http://www.alcsearch.com[/embed]
item.excerpt:encoded: An Arabic #learner #corpus (free registration), the interface is very nice with a useful set of filters.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: great to see more openly licensed corpora appearing on the teaching, learning and researching scene
yes indeed, do you know if there is a specific list of open corpuses anywhere?
I don't know of such a list but it would be a good idea for the corpus list keepers to add this meta information so people know what the issues are around reuse and permissions.

item.content:encoded: A couple of very nice #corpus based tools - WriteAway http://writeaway.nlpweb.org/ and Linggle http://linggle.com WriteAway shows examples of the pattern of words so great potential for students to figure out how to structure their sentences. Linggle is like a souped up just-the-word as it allows you to use part of speech tags and various other filters h/t Yuichiro Kobayashi @langstat [embed]http://writeaway.nlpweb.org[/embed]

hi this might help http://www.decode.waseda.ac.jp/announcement/documents-for-2015-03-07-08/JasonChang.pdf#page=49 it's like google autocomplete and shows not only example sentences but the patterns sentences are formed from
Thank you very much

These are excellent! I think the WriteAway is good for Japanese learners, since they have a translator as well. But there isn't any other description of who manages this site. Maybe this is a student project?
the pdf linked above gives name of person, he's from a computer science team based in Taiwan apparently

item.title: The Compleat Word Lister is a tool originally developed to test the claim that all texts have 50% of words which...
item.dc:creator: MuraNava
item.content:encoded:
The Compleat Word Lister is a tool originally developed to test the claim that all texts have 50% of words which only occur once (singletons). If true (which the tool shows is not) it would mean that recycling vocabulary in texts for pedagogical purposes would be impossible.
See #LexTutor FB group for further explanation
[embed]http://www.lextutor.ca/freq/comp/[/embed]

item.dc:creator: MuraNava
item.content:encoded: CQPwebInABox is an #CQP image that you can load using virtualbox. Interesting, will test it. Info from corpus4u.org: --------- Lancaster University has announced the release of CQPwebInABox. See Andrew Hardie's message below: Hi everybody, This is just a quick note to announce the availability of CQPwebInABox – a virtual machine image containing a pre-installed copy of CQPweb. This will allow you to have your own copy of CQPweb on your own computer, where you can install your own corpora! The image (1.6GB) can be downloaded here: https://sourceforge.net/projects/cwb.../CQPwebInABox/ To run it, you will need to install VirtualBox (although I believe other virtualisation tools can also use the same file format, I haven’t yet tested this). You can get VirtualBox here: https://www.virtualbox.org/wiki/Downloads Then “import appliance” from the .ova download. The virtual machine runs Linux – however, I have set it up in such a way as to make the interface as similar to Windows as possible. So don’t fear the Linux! I will create some video tutorials & put them on YouTube as soon as I can. Feedback welcome. best Andrew. -------------
item.excerpt:encoded: CQPwebInABox is an #CQP image that you can load using virtualbox.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
did quick test, works well it. comes with BNCsampler corpus and Mandarin Chinese corpus.
you do need a fast processor and as much RAM as you can to get better performance though on a virtual machine

item.title: Notes for AMALGrAM 2.0 a multi-word expression and semantic tagger
item.dc:creator: MuraNava
item.content:encoded: Notes for AMALGrAM 2.0 a multi-word expression and semantic tagger The tagger expects input file to be part of speech (POS) tagged and in a tabbed format. Also there needs to be a space between sentences (https://github.com/nschneid/pysupersensetagger/blob/master/README.md#input-format) 1. So first we need to split the words in a file into separate lines: tr -s '[[:space:]]' '\n' < file Note this is for a file already with spaces in between punctuations, for proper tokenisations use the stanford tokenizer: java edu.stanford.nlp.process.PTBTokenizer file update been having problems running standford tokenizer so use the following instead: grep -Eo '\w+|[^\w ]' input.txt 2. POS tag using stanford tagger with -tokenize false flag java -mx300m -classpath stanford-postagger.jar edu.stanford.nlp.tagger.maxent.MaxentTagger -model models/english-bidirectional-distsim.tagger -tokenize false -textFile file 3. Insert newline after tagged full stop: sed 's/\._\./&\n/g' file 4. Convert underscores into Tab delimited: sed 's/_/\t/g' file 5. Finally run file in pysupersensetagger (AMALGrAM) ./sst.sh file See also: part 2 notes [https://plus.google.com/+MuraNava/posts/7mhfUphECCL] [embed]https://github.com/nschneid/pysupersensetagger/blob/master/README.md#input-format[/embed]
item.excerpt:encoded: Notes for AMALGrAM 2.0 a multi-word expression and semantic tagger

item.title: GraphColl is an interesting new #corpus interface #tool
item.dc:creator: MuraNava
item.content:encoded: GraphColl is an interesting new #corpus interface #tool . It can visualise the collocations of a corpus in graph form. It also produces KWIC concordance lines and has a number of statistical filters for the graphs. Get program from this page - http://www.extremetomato.com/projects/graphcoll/ and user pdf from http://corpora.lancs.ac.uk/stats/docs/graphcoll_manual.pdf note for OSX users: expand the window in the new graph tab to see the search box [embed]http://www.extremetomato.com/projects/graphcoll[/embed]
item.excerpt:encoded: GraphColl is an interesting new #corpus interface #tool

item.title: Apparently there is a section in COCA-BYU Fiction called Juvenile.
item.dc:creator: MuraNava
item.content:encoded: Apparently there is a section in COCA-BYU Fiction called Juvenile. This can be handy to find language items that would suit low level students as we can assume that the language for such fiction would be simpler. There is a list of the children's books in the following excel sheet:[http://corpus.byu.edu/coca/files/juvenile-fiction.xlsx]. h/t corporalist Related: Graded readers for simpler language examples [https://plus.google.com/+MuraNava/posts/XvojJEv3c7Z] PATTIE (Preschoolers- and Teenagers-oriented Texts in English) corpus [http://124.193.83.252/cqp/pattie/], (test for username and password; this has Peppa Pig amongst others)
item.excerpt:encoded: Apparently there is a section in COCA-BYU Fiction called Juvenile.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Thanks for the post Mura, also the link on graded reader corpora  [https://plus.google.com/+MuraNava/posts/XvojJEv3c7Z] has made me rethink the "accessibility" issue of DDL, that the concordances should be comprehensible in order to have an impact.
Hi Peter, very glad you find it of use. :) Been playing with the PATTIE corpus a bit, very neat.

item.title: Spoken Corpora
item.dc:creator: MuraNava
item.content:encoded: Spoken Corpora Publically available spoken corpora is rarer than the most rare thing you can think of. A couple of people have been enquiring and my latest look has turned up ORTOLANG Speech and Language Data Repository (SLDR/ORTOLANG) [http://sldr.org/index.php?lang=en&offset=0&nbre=20], hat tip Yutaka Ishii ‏@yishii_0207. In particular there is the Open ANC [http://sldr.org/voir_depot.php?lang=en&id=770&prefix=sldr] which includes the Charlotte Narrative corpus [http://nsv.uncc.edu/nsv/narratives]. This may be of use to people looking for a 'conversation' corpus and looking to do 'backchannel' language research. (those were the two queries recently) [embed]http://sldr.org/index.php?lang=en&offset=0&nbre=20[/embed]
item.excerpt:encoded: Spoken Corpora

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: a couple of more open speech corpora (HCRC Map Task Corpus, Switchboard corpus) available from https://corpling.uis.georgetown.edu/cqp/ [scroll down page for speech corpora]

item.title: AntConc Alternatives
item.dc:creator: MuraNava
item.content:encoded: AntConc Alternatives Note this a very short comment on some free alternatives to AntConc. I have not tested all the programs fully yet. There are now a number of free concordance programs that could be used instead of AntConc and I wanted to quickly look at 3 that may be useful for language teachers. I’ll start with corpkit [http://interrogator.github.io/corpkit/] as it has been widely shared on social media recently. This was originally a set of Python scripts and has now got a graphical user interface (GUI only for Mac OS X at the moment). This is aimed at linguists as it has a number of complex features. Unless you are already very keen on corpus linguistics this software won’t have much utility. The next program is called CasualConc [https://sites.google.com/site/casualconc/] it is only available for Mac OS X. Although the interface requires bit of a learning curve especially if you are used to AntConc you can get started on using it fairly quickly. If you are so inclined its more advanced features make it stand out such as various statistical calculations, visualizations and experimental features such as a vocabulary profiler. The last program is MonoconcEsy [https://www.academia.edu/16716002/MonoconcEsy]. This is a windows based program and is very easy to get started with. It does show its age though in terms of the user interface experience. My personnel recommendation for language teachers would be to have a try of CasualConc if you have Mac OS X otherwise stick to AntConc. If I had a windows system I would try MonoconcEsy more and see how I got on with it. I currently run it on a virtual system which is not very convenient to do regularly. h/t twitterverse for corpkit, Yasu ‏@casualconc for CasualConc, M.K ‏@usage_based for MonoconcEsy see also: CorpusExplorer [https://plus.google.com/+MuraNava/posts/doqUJ73266x]
item.excerpt:encoded: AntConc Alternatives

item.title: Between genres: science journalism and science research
item.dc:creator: MuraNava
item.content:encoded: Between genres: science journalism and science research Julie Moore  has a nice post [http://lexicoblog.blogspot.co.uk/2016/01/semi-academic-sources-in-eap-interview.html] on the use of science journalism articles in an EAP settings and how important it is to make students aware that these types of texts are very different to journal research articles. She points out that part of the appeal of magazine articles on science is that abstracts in journals “are incredibly densely packed and require a certain degree of skill to decode.” The PLOS (Public Library of Science) website asks authors to write an author summary which is “Distinct from the scientific abstract, the Author Summary is included in the article to make findings accessible to an audience of both scientists and non-scientists." This presents a possible halfway house for EAP students. The PLOS abstracts are restricted to mainly biology and medical domains and not all papers have author summaries. One could simply copy paste abstracts and author summaries from the web pages. Or one could semi-automate this. There is a nice scraper called quickscrape [https://github.com/ContentMine/quickscrape] which allows you to download articles from various journals. Follow the instructions on the github site to set it up and to understand the quickscrape commands. The configuration for plos journals can be modified so that you only need to download the abstracts. In the journal-scrapers/scrapers/plos.json file modify the file like so: {   "url": "plos.*\\.org",   "elements": {     "abstract_html": {       "selector": "(//div[contains(@class,'abstract’)])[2]”            }       } } The number in the above config just downloads the author summary, to download the original abstract change the number to 1. There seems to be a limitation if you start hitting the journal server too much so be wary of that. Here are the files for 10 abstracts and 10 author summaries [https://drive.google.com/open?id=0B7FW2BYaBgeiNExJS2FiZzVpYW8]
item.excerpt:encoded: Between genres: science journalism and science research

item.title: COCA search terms for clauses
item.dc:creator: MuraNava
item.content:encoded: COCA search terms for clauses Although I had known how to find some clauses such as -ing clauses in COCA before, I had trouble finding infinitive clauses and noun phrases. Recently I watched a video about motion charts [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=E9Nhex7JSLA] which showed how to find various clauses. This is relevant for me when teaching reporting verbs in the TOEIC exam. As I was always stumped by what example sentences to come up with for say the verb claim followed by an infinitive clause. To do this search you use the term [claim] to [v?i*] and we get such examples as claim to be, claim to have, claim to know. To search for what noun phrases follow claim + that clauses you use [claim] that.[cs*] * [n*]. We get example such as claim that the state, claim that the U.S., claim that the President. As I mentioned -ing clauses are straight forward to find you just add [v?g*] to the end of your search. For full clauses you can add [p*] [v*] to the search, so for the claim example we could use [claim] [p*] [v*] and get results such as claimed he was, claimed it was, claimed he had. The above search terms are also useful to get examples of causative verbs that are also required in the TOEIC.
item.excerpt:encoded: COCA search terms for clauses

item.title: Exploring audio clip tools using the BNC spoken corpus
item.dc:creator: MuraNava
item.content:encoded: Exploring audio clip tools using the BNC spoken corpus There are now a number of audio corpus interfaces available that allow you to get examples of spoken English. These vary from Movies and TV shows such as Playphrase (http://playphrase.me) and Yarn (http://getyarn.io/yarn-popular), h/t Sandy Millin ‏@sandymillin, to Youtube videos such as Youglish (http://youglish.com/) and Divii (http://www.divii.org/). A question arises as to what search terms to use, i.e. what are frequent terms that we could use in class? In order to get a list of frequent terms one can use the Spokes interface to the Spoken BNC (British National Corpus).[http://pelcra.clarin-pl.eu/SpokesBNC/#explore/kp/0/100] It has a feature that lists all the common formulae such as the following top 3: thank you very much i don't know isn't it One now has a nice base in order to explore the tools mentioned initially. Of course one must bear in mind that the BNC is dated so current conversational English will not be represented well. Thanks to Cara Leopold @eltinfrance for prompting this note.
item.excerpt:encoded: Exploring audio clip tools using the BNC spoken corpus

item.title: BootCat Top Tip
item.dc:creator: MuraNava
item.content:encoded: BootCat Top Tip If you use BootCat here is a command to help you separate the collected corpus into individual files using the CURRENT URL line as a separator in a regex: awk '/CURRENT URL/{g++} { print $0 > g".txt"}' corpus.txt Be careful when copy pasting this command into your command line that the apostrophe ' is straight and not curly. related: BootCat custom URL: [https://eflnotes.wordpress.com/2014/10/08/building-your-own-corpus-bootcat/] BootCat seeding: [https://plus.google.com/+MuraNava/posts/8JjUVKyA8FE]
item.excerpt:encoded: BootCat Top Tip

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Command lines are awesome! I should look into this software.
hi, please do Peter : )

item.title: Netcollo
item.dc:creator: MuraNava
item.content:encoded: Netcollo Looks like a new improved version of [netcollo.stringnet.org]. Allows you to search for collocations and results indicate whether your search collocation is good or not. Help page - [http://www.netcollo.info/netcollo/manual.php] h/t Pérez-Paredes ‏@perezparedes [embed]http://netcollo.info/netcollo[/embed]
item.excerpt:encoded: Netcollo

item.title: Email corpora
item.dc:creator: MuraNava
item.content:encoded: Email corpora 1) The most famous is no doubt the ENRON corpus e.g. [https://www.cs.cmu.edu/~enron/] or the ENRON Sent corpus [http://savethevowels.org/enronsent/] 2) There is the Business Letter Corpus [http://www.someya-net.com/concordancer/], shame interface to this is limited. 3) British Columbia Conversation Corpora (BC3): Email corpus [https://www.cs.ubc.ca/cs-research/lci/research-groups/natural-language-processing/bc3.html#email] 4) SPAM and non-SPAM email datasets [http://csmining.org/index.php/data.html] 5) Hilary Clinton email archive by Wikileaks [https://wikileaks.org/clinton-emails/]. 6) US Democratic National Convention email archive [https://wikileaks.org/dnc-emails/]. Thanks to Laura Adele Soracco for prompting this post. related: Enron corpus primer tutorial [https://plus.google.com/+MuraNava/posts/eMuCSNRPVRt]
item.excerpt:encoded: Email corpora

item.title: Australia 2015/2016 Corpus:
item.dc:creator: MuraNava
item.content:encoded: Australia 2015/2016 Corpus: From the webpage: "The corpus ‘Australia 2015/2016’ includes all articles from major Australian newspapers published from August 2015 to July 2016 that include the key term ‘Australia’ or ‘Australian(s)’ in the title. Altogether, the corpus contains over 7 million tokens in almost 13,000 articles from 18 newspapers. The corpus thus reflects one year of printed media coverage of topics directly relevant to Australia." h/t Annabelle Lukin ‏@annabellelukin [embed]http://www.annabellelukin.com/corpus-resources.html[/embed]

item.dc:creator: MuraNava
item.content:encoded: Academic Word Suggestion Machine AWSuM Apart from the very neat acronym this tool is worth exploring. It provides suggestions for writing an applied linguistics research paper using n-grams, paper sections and moves. It also links to a concordancer of the corpus of app ling research articles as well as external links to some potentially useful corpus tools. Introduction video link [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kngTcM-0MiE] h/t i_narrator @i_narrator [embed]http://langtest.jp/awsum/[/embed]

item.title: Comparing modal verbs in COCA
item.dc:creator: MuraNava
item.content:encoded: Comparing modal verbs in COCA This arose from a student query in class. One can easily compare words that are similar in COCA fairly easily. For example comparing the modal verbs will and shall gives quite a nice results screen when the collocates are the verbs following the modals - [http://corpus.byu.edu/coca/?c=coca&q=52703898]. The results show that will is about 52 times as frequent as shall, and that the verb collocates of shall seem quite formal. Comparing may and might does not give as stark a difference [http://corpus.byu.edu/coca/?c=coca&q=52703967] though some patterns are detectable for example the use of might have for speculation and that may is maybe more formal. To investigate whether may is more formal we can use the chart feature to check genre/register distribution. The distribution for might is balanced with maybe a peak in fiction register [http://corpus.byu.edu/coca/?c=coca&q=52704091], however for may we can clearly see dominant use in the academic register [http://corpus.byu.edu/coca/?c=coca&q=52704056].
item.excerpt:encoded: Comparing modal verbs in COCA

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Hi Sorry for disturbing again Could u tell me pls what is the rate error of antconc Whenever I put a phrasal verb many times I got different frequency counts . Once as 40 another as 80 then sometimes 20 .. what is the explanation for this??? Thanks a lot
hello are you using a tagged corpus?
No it is untagged
can you give an example of search term you are using? and which corpus?
Brown and lob .. came up ... I searched for this phrasal verb ... in its different tokens .. once it gives me 70 then 40 then 50 ..

hmm tried with brown and lob with search term come up|came up|coming up, i get 61 and 62 hits respectively
i don't get your figures?
Yes .. true I got in 2 of the attempts 61 - 63 ... n other attempts 44 and 38 ... thanks again for being cooperative ..
do you make sure to [clear all tools and files] before loading corpus?
Yes I am sure I cleared all the files ND tools .. I uploaded brown only .. and I cleared research box.. this confuses m ...does the program hv an error rate??!sorry for bothering
what do you mean by error rate?
The accuracy of the program ... does the program ensure a percentage of accuracy? I tried about 300 phrasal verbs and I got different results every time I worked on t ... thanks a lot

it is simply counting so there should not be an error; i can't reproduce your results so there must be some issue at your end? - check u have latest version of AntConc - re-download the brown corpus - try search again
OK I will do thank u sooooo much
no worries good luck

item.title: Classroom activities for speaking
item.dc:creator: MuraNava
item.content:encoded: Classroom activities for speaking Nice set of worksheets based on the Trinity-Lancaster Spoken Learner Corpus. There is currently 1 worksheet at B1 level and 7 at B2: B1 Successful speakers… are clear about their opinions B2 Successful speakers… ask questions B2 Successful speakers… make sure they understand B2 Successful speakers… use a variety of ways to manage hesitation B2 Successful speakers… show they are listening B2 Successful speakers… take responsibility for the conversation B2 Successful speakers… use a wide range of expressions B2 Successful speakers… are clear about their opinions h/t vaclav ‏@vaclavbrezina [embed]http://www.trinitycollege.com/site/?id=3662[/embed]
item.excerpt:encoded: Classroom activities for speaking

item.title: The Corpus of Multilingual Opinion Essays by College Students (MOECS)
item.dc:creator: MuraNava
item.content:encoded: The Corpus of Multilingual Opinion Essays by College Students (MOECS) From the site: The Corpus of Multilingual Opinion Essays by College Students (MOECS) is a collection of essays by college students. This is open to any researchers only for a research purpose. The corpus includes essays of English (collected in Australia including international students with English as a first language background), Japanese, Korean, and Taiwanese first language (L1), and English of Japanese learners, Japanese of English learners, Japanese of Korean learners, and Japanese of Taiwanese learners. The registration process is the simplist I have seen to get the corpus, nice : ) h/t VARIENG ‏@Varieng [embed]http://www.u-sacred-heart.ac.jp/okugiri/links/moecs/moecs.html[/embed]
item.excerpt:encoded: The Corpus of Multilingual Opinion Essays by College Students (MOECS)

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: I note "for research purposes" but does that exclude pedogogical usage I wonder.
There is a contact person to ask
Mura Nava Thanks Mura. It looks like a great resource. Even if the usage is limited, I am sure it will offer insights.
do report back here Peter if you find out

item.dc:creator: MuraNava
item.content:encoded: Spoken Wikipedia Corpus "In addition to per-word alignments, we also provide phoneme-level alignments for both German and English, generated by MAUS. This is, as far as we know, the largest corpus of freely-available aligned speech for both German and Dutch and the largest freely-available corpus of aligned factual speech for English." h/t Diane Nicholls [embed]http://nats.gitlab.io/swc/[/embed]

item.title: Keyword comparison available with spoken BNC 1994
item.dc:creator: MuraNava
item.content:encoded: Keyword comparison available with spoken BNC 1994 Changes to how words are used between 1994 and 2014 can be looked at in the Spoken BNC2014 corpus. For example ooh, aye, bloody drops out of use in 2014 compared to 1994 h/t BNC2014 @BNC_2014 related Sign Up for BNC2014 access [https://plus.google.com/u/0/+MuraNava/posts/EHYuJoQe8kB]
item.excerpt:encoded: Keyword comparison available with spoken BNC 1994

item.title: Multi-word searches in BNC2014 and BNC1994
item.dc:creator: MuraNava
item.content:encoded: Multi-word searches in BNC2014 and BNC1994 Multiword searches in the spoken BNC2014 can be done by: (?longest) [pos=".*\d\d"]+ and to look for a particular length e.g. 5 words: [pos=".*5\d"]{5} For spoken BNC1994 use following terms: (+)+ Note the list used to tag multi-words can be found here: [http://ucrel.lancs.ac.uk/bnc2sampler/ditto.htm] h/t Andrew Hardie @HardieResearch
item.excerpt:encoded: Multi-word searches in BNC2014 and BNC1994

item.title: New 14 billion iWeb corpus at BYU
item.dc:creator: MuraNava
item.content:encoded: New 14 billion iWeb corpus at BYU Not yet launched officially ; ) What is new here is that the downloaded web sites were systematically collected unlike most web corpora which are very random and noisy. Very nice features for the top 60,000 words e.g. a comprehensive word profiler; topics; a SketchEngine "wordsketch" like feature for collocations and clusters; words associated with particular websites; a related words feature; search by syllable stress. And total word count is about 14 billion! (22 million web pages from nearly 95,000 different websites) Remember you read it here first : ) [embed]https://corpus.byu.edu/iweb/[/embed]
item.excerpt:encoded: New 14 billion iWeb corpus at BYU

item.title: Text Variation Explorer (TVE)
item.dc:creator: MuraNava
item.content:encoded: Text Variation Explorer (TVE) "TVE is an interactive Java tool for exploring the effect of window size on three common linguistic measures: type-token ratio, proportion of hapax legomena, and average word length. In addition, TVE can cluster the text fragments according to a user-given set of words by applying principal component analysis (PCA)." h/t Corpora List [embed]http://www.uta.fi/sis/tauchi/virg/projects/dammoc/tve.html[/embed]

item.title: Hi Corpus Linguists. Help needed with EFCAMDAT, please!
item.dc:creator: ChrisBunyan
item.content:encoded:
Hi Corpus Linguists. Help needed with EFCAMDAT, please!
I'm interested in how people use wh- phrases after prepositions (e.g. ...interested IN HOW people use wh-...). I've used BNC to analyse native speaker/proficient-language user texts. Now I'm using EFCAMDAT to look at how students may avoid it (as a result of oversimplification in ELT materials etc.) and I want to compare the corpora's frequencies.
But I've hit a couple of problems: 1) In the Add PoS: drop down menu, prepositions are lumped in with subordinate clause conjunctions (why?); 2) If I make the query about wh- adverbs, determiners or pronouns used as the object of a preposition, e.g. [(pos="WP.*") & (dg-hpos="pobj")], then I get 0 matches returned (at least from the level 7 scripts I'm currently searching) which surely can't be right, can it?.
Very specific question, I know, but any ideas, pointers, general help would be much appreciated.
item.excerpt:encoded: Hi Corpus Linguists. Help needed with EFCAMDAT, please!

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
hi chris
should it not be dg-rel not dg-hpos ?

Thanks for the guidance, Mura Nava. Returning better results. Now I need to work out how to label the Wh- adverb phrase (where, how) as I'm guessing these are not coming up as objects because they're not noun phrases.
Many thanks,
Chris
great, how many results do you get now? let us know if you do a write up of your investigation :)

item.title: Ce site présente 710 pièces de théâtre et spectacles de 1610 à 1802, en vers (plus de 630 000 vers) et en prose à...
item.dc:creator: LinguaF
item.content:encoded:
Ce site présente 710 pièces de théâtre et spectacles de 1610 à 1802, en vers (plus de 630 000 vers) et en prose à consulter ou éditer comportant des fonctions de recherche et de statistiques de vocabulaire ou sur les rimes. Vous pouvez aussi rechercher les occurences d'un mot dans un texte. De Du Ryer à Voltaire, en passant par Corneille, Molière, Racine, Dancourt, Marivaux : le corpus est accompagné de plus cents textes polémiques ou théoriques encadrant le corpus dans son contexte historique. Les pièces peuvent être comparées deux à deux dans leur structure globale, soit avec leur vocabulaire.
[embed]http://www.theatre-classique.fr/[/embed]
item.excerpt:encoded: Ce site présente 710 pièces de théâtre et spectacles de 1610 à 1802, en vers (plus de 630 000 vers) et en prose à...

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: c'est chouette merci :)
Cher, Mura Nava! Tout le plaisir est pour moi. :)

item.title: This dictionary is based on the 100 million word British National Corpus.
item.dc:creator: LinguaF
item.content:encoded: This dictionary is based on the 100 million word British National Corpus. www.ozdic.com brings you a completely new type of dictionary that will help the learners of English to write and speak natural-sounding English.  Collocations - common word combinations such as 'bright idea' or 'talk freely' - are the essential building blocks of natural-sounding English. The dictionary contains over 150,000 collocations for nearly 9,000 headwords. The dictionary shows all the words that are commonly used in combination with each headword: nouns, verbs, adjectives, adverbs, and prepositions as well as common phrases.  Internet searches were made to ensure the most up-to-date usage for fast changing areas of language such as computing. [embed]http://www.ozdic.com/[/embed]
item.excerpt:encoded: This dictionary is based on the 100 million word British National Corpus.

WORD AND PHRASE .INFO. MARK DAVIES | BYU | COCA CORPUS ...
Search/browse most accurate word frequency lists of English. Detailed on words and phrases in texts: frequency, collocates, concordances, etc. ... New: limit searches to just academic English
[embed]http://www.wordandphrase.info/[/embed]
item.excerpt:encoded: WORD AND PHRASE .INFO. MARK DAVIES | BYU | COCA CORPUS ...

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
Can anyone explain the inconsistencies in the 'Analyze texts' tool on Word and Phrase? I wanted to demonstrate to one of my MA students that W.E.Henley's poem 'Invictus' includes a LOT of low frequency vocabulary (hence is unsuitable for anythign but the most advanced students). I cut and pasted it in, and, bizarrely, it coloured 'be', 'shall' and 'years' as in the >3000 band. Yet when I clicked on the 'See lists' button, 'be' and 'years' were not listed, while 'shall', still in the >3000 band, is in fact at rank order 2211. Likewise 'gate', while colour coded for >3000, is ranked at 2020. Am I missing something here?
In case you want to try for yourself, here is the poem:
Out of the night that covers me, Black as the pit from pole to pole, I thank whatever gods may be For my unconquerable soul. In the fell clutch of circumstance I have not winced nor cried aloud. Under the bludgeonings of chance My head is bloody, but unbowed. Beyond this place of wrath and tears Looms but the Horror of the shade, And yet the menace of the years Finds and shall find me unafraid. It matters not how strait the gate, How charged with punishments the scroll, I am the master of my fate: I am the captain of my soul.

Scott Thornbury hi Scott sorry only just read this now, yep i can confirm odd results you got, have you tried notifying Mark Davies? i get more sensible results for be, shall, years with http://corpora.lancs.ac.uk/vocab/

also just noticed that the lancs site has a complexity analyser based on word endings of verbs and nouns http://corpora.lancs.ac.uk/vocab/analyse_morph.php, something for your MA students to consider for next time Scott :)

item.title: Ana Frankenberg (2012) has written what I think is the best recent rationale for #language #teachers to...
item.dc:creator: MuraNava
item.content:encoded: Ana Frankenberg  (2012) has written what I think is the best recent rationale for #language #teachers to incorporate a #corpus approach. Promoting it as just another tool (albeit powerful one) in the everyday teacher's toolkit. A must read: http://www.academia.edu/3368339/Integrating_corpora_with_everyday_language_teaching [embed]http://www.academia.edu/3368339/Integrating_corpora_with_everyday_language_teaching[/embed]
item.excerpt:encoded: Ana Frankenberg (2012) has written what I think is the best recent rationale for #language #teachers to...

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Excellent article with lots of very practical examples. I couldn't agree more with the author.That's what I personally need - a shift in perspective. I'm a bit more careful (or skeptical) about the hands-on approach, though. In my experience not very many students really take to it. If there's internet access and the teacher is present and helping each student individually, it's fine. I used COCA like this in an academic writing course, mostly for reference - "if you can't find what you need in a dictionary, try this..." At the end of the course, most students were quite positive about using the corpus - when I asked them to write a short reflective piece about the course, many of them mentioned it as one of the things they liked. But will it be part of their toolkit when they keep writing in English once the course is over? I'm not so sure. Also, it's an exceptional course - with plenty of time, when I have the freedom to set up my own syllabus relevant to my students' needs... And it's the only course I dared to use a corpus "hands-on" on a regular basis :) Ooops, should I post this in the discussion section, perhaps?

thanks Monika Sobejko Monika for reporting your experiences of having students directly use corpora
i agree that such a direct approach has many challenges since corpora results can be overwhelming
for example not just the amount of concordance lines but the surrounding unknown words in those lines
one approach is to get students to look at class made corpus of their writing, that way any problematic language can be seen in contexts of familiar words
my approach is indirect; i find a collection of texts, introduce a single text from that collection by using traditional reading approaches; then introduce concordances from the whole text collection looking at particular words and grammar.
this is with a multi-media class so it is an english for specfic purpose context; for general english classes i rarely use even an indirect corpus approach!
at the moment for an exam class that uses a set book i am seeing how to use a corpus of listening transcripts from that book...

thanks, Mura. as i said it was a very different class to the ones i usully teach. This year i have ESP students (some groups of archaeologystudents and some of computer science students), so your experience with the multimedia class is directly relevant to what I'm doing. But it means building one's own corpus (collection of texts) - how big are typically your collections (your corpora) for such analyses of grammar and vocabulary to work well?

current multi-media one is about 300K word tokens; previous multi-media one was about 170K word tokens
my current exam listening transcript one is about 11K word tokens!
when doing home made corpora total size is not as important as relevancy of text and how you integrate it into the rest of the course
you can of course supplement with use of massive corpora like COCA to make better generalisations

Wow! Sounds very impressive. i really like the idea of turning the listening transcript into a corpus. Usually, transcripts are 'underexploited' in my classes, and i always feel i could do more with transcripts. Sometimes i simply photocopy them and turn into gap-fill exercises. In the ESP classes i do a lot of reading and vocabulary work based on texts. I often get students to suggest articles they want to read, and then prepare exercises based on those articles... Having a corpus will be useful, and i can think of ways of integrating it into what we do in class. Choosing relevant text will be much more of a challenge.
thanks for all the tips! Still, it's a very tempting icing :)

thanks for sharing your experiences
am sure there is mileage to be gotten from that icing metaphor :)

item.title: Corpus-based exercise formats
item.dc:creator: MuraNava
item.content:encoded: Corpus-based exercise formats Using Corpora to Help Teach Difficult-to-distinguish English Words (2013) by Dilin Liu, section 3 gives a nice format for #teachers to present #corpus derived (from #COCA ) exercises. Ex1 type is a fill in the gap, Ex2 is a replace keeping original sentence meaning and Ex3 is an error detection one with a translation of corrected sentence. See the following which is extracted from exercises on differentiating the synonyms incorrectly and wrongly from page 37 and 38: (1) Exercise 1: Decide whether incorrectly or wrongly fills in each blank better semantically; write either if you believe either adverb works equally well. a. The United Nations TV had --------- identified Mr. Smith as the ambassador (either) (2) Exercise 2: Decide whether incorrectly or wrongly or either adverb may replace each underlined word while keeping the original meaning and tone of the sentence. a. It has been found that some of the prisoners were unjustly convicted. (wrongly) (3) Exercise 3. Some of the underlined uses of incorrectly and wrongly are inappropriate. Identify and correct them. Then translate the sentences into Korean. a. I incorrectly identified Brit Hume as being located at the White House right now. (correct) Some of the sentences have been adapted e.g.: sentence clauses into full sentences: The tape was acquired from United Nations TV which had incorrectly identified the ambassador —> The United Nations TV had incorrectly/wrongly identified Mr. Smith as the ambassador; filling in ellipsis: David Hilliard's title --> David Hilliard's job title. more or less wholesale rewrites: Some of the prisoners USA TODAY contacted -- and their lawyers -- were stunned to find out that they were imprisoned for something that turned out not to be a federal crime —> It has been found that some of the prisoners were unjustly convicted. The article does not mention whether sentences were changed to suit student level and/or readibility. http://journal.kate.or.kr/wp-content/uploads/2015/01/kate_68_3_2.pdf
item.excerpt:encoded: Corpus-based exercise formats

item.title: Very neat summary by Anthony Schmidt of #corpus analysis of #errors by French learners of English.
item.dc:creator: MuraNava
item.content:encoded: Very neat summary by Anthony Schmidt of #corpus analysis of #errors by French learners of English. The study does make a good point about effects of focusing on sentence vs larger discourse on verb tense choice by these French students. Although the two corpora used were the same size no information is given in the study on whether the data came from the same number of students. I would imagine that analysis of individual errors would have complemented the information from the averaging of errors over the two corpora? The discussion in part 5 of the study was useful to me as a teacher in France as it outlines some issues learners here have when choosing #verb tenses. http://www.anthonyteacher.com/blog/researchbites/research-bites-grammar-beyond-the-sentence?utm_content=buffer346d0&utm_medium=social&utm_source=twitter.com&utm_campaign=buffer h/t Leo Selivan  [embed]http://www.anthonyteacher.com/blog/researchbites/research-bites-grammar-beyond-the-sentence?utm_content=buffer346d0&utm_medium=social&utm_source=twitter.com&utm_campaign=buffer[/embed]
item.excerpt:encoded: Very neat summary by Anthony Schmidt of #corpus analysis of #errors by French learners of English.
