item.title: Bigger is not necessarily better
item.dc:creator: MuraNava
item.content:encoded: Bigger is not necessarily better It was interesting to read that a large #corpus such as #COCA -BYU can actually bias the language collected.  Before I go on how do you think a large corpus can bias the data? This paper - On Using Corpus Frequency, Dispersion and Chronological Data to Help Identify Useful Collocations [http://www.smartsmart.org/researchsample.pdf] reports that a lot of the collocations it found were related to food and cooking. That is because the magazines and newspapers used by COCA regularly had recipes. Another bias the study discusses is with the spoken section of COCA which uses a lot of television news and talk shows hence the language reflects those of newscasters and talk show hosts. Finally the study highlights the lack of a specific business sub corpus such as there is for academic langauge, at the moment business language is spread across spoken, magazine and newspaper sources but not with particularly high frequencies. [embed]http://www.smartsmart.org/researchsample.pdf[/embed]
item.excerpt:encoded: Bigger is not necessarily better

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Hi James thanks for clarifying this, I do recognise that the main aim of your paper was other than bias in COCA. I found the bias about food a nice corpus 'fact' to hook a G+ post. :)

item.title: Following on the queries about which #corpus tools are used, Chris #Tribble has kindly shared a paper titled...
item.dc:creator: MuraNava
item.content:encoded: Following on the queries about which #corpus tools are used, Chris #Tribble has kindly shared a paper titled Teaching and language corpora: Perspectives from a personal journey [https://googledrive.com/host/0B7FW2BYaBgeiTWRkVS1RMXViNlE/13Tribblefinal_rev.pdf] from a forthcoming volume. It comprises a section on the history of corpus tools in language teaching with citations to seminal work by community member John Higgins . And a section summarising the 2012 #survey of Corpora in ELT, the screenshot shows responses to most useful tool question (and to answer our original question it seems amongst teachers Wordsmith Tools is the favoured offline tool). A total of 560 people answered the survey from some 63 countries. There is a lot of other interesting information in the paper, go check it out. Also if you want to look at a brief history of computerised corpus tools have a look at: http://timemapper.okfnlabs.org/muranava/history-of-computerised-corpus-tools [embed]https://googledrive.com/host/0B7FW2BYaBgeiTWRkVS1RMXViNlE/mostuseful-corpustool.png[/embed]
item.excerpt:encoded: Following on the queries about which #corpus tools are used, Chris #Tribble has kindly shared a paper titled...

item.title: Paper...
item.dc:creator: MuraNava
item.content:encoded: Paper [https://www.academia.edu/3631516/Computer-Mediated_Collocation_Resources_for_Exploring_Word_Choice_in_English_Academic_Writing] describing various #onlinetools students can use to help with #collocation choices. It has a very nice table assessing the tools according to the following six questions (using example of extent): (1) I want to explore extent. What are some of its collocates? (2) Is big extent a collocation? I want to just type it in; if it’s not a collocation, there should be 0 hits. (3) Is the correct collocation big extent or large extent? I want to search two phrases at the same time. (4) What adjectives commonly precede extent? (5) What adjectives commonly precede extent that mean something like big extent? (6) It’s on the tip of my tongue! I want to do a wildcard search. It makes the emininently sensible suggestion of getting students to use multiple tools to triangulate searches. h/t M.K @usage_based
item.excerpt:encoded: Paper...

item.title: A brief history of computer concordances
item.dc:creator: MuraNava
item.content:encoded: A brief history of computer concordances A nice find by Michael Brown​​​  which describes more of the humanities side of concordancing. The Language Log blog [http://languagelog.ldc.upenn.edu/nll/?p=26769] which links this piece also links to an hilariously tragic David Lodge extract on the dangers of corpus linguistics for writers [http://itre.cis.upenn.edu/~myl/languagelog/archives/000361.html]. Which reminds me to see if anyone can identify the corpus David Lodge uses in one of his later books? [https://plus.google.com/+MuraNava/posts/HF8hWXAUZfh] related: Corpus Linguistics: The past [https://plus.google.com/+MuraNava/posts/FBWcemupNMu] [embed]http://www.colorado.edu/ArtsSciences/CCRH/history.html[/embed]
item.excerpt:encoded: A brief history of computer concordances

item.title: Use of positive and negative words in scientific PubMed abstracts between 1974 and 2014: retrospective analysis
item.dc:creator: MuraNava
item.content:encoded: Use of positive and negative words in scientific PubMed abstracts between 1974 and 2014: retrospective analysis A very nice study showing changes (or lack of) in use of positive, negative, neutral & random words in biomedical abstracts. The appendix includes the searches the authors did for you to replicate. It was interesting to discover that lexical searches on pubmed produces trend graphs which you can download. Nice. h/t Achilleas Kostoulas  [embed]http://www.bmj.com/content/351/bmj.h6467[/embed]
item.excerpt:encoded: Use of positive and negative words in scientific PubMed abstracts between 1974 and 2014: retrospective analysis

item.title: Chères amies, chers amis, permettez-moi de vous présenter la prochaine journées d'études internationales de...
item.dc:creator: CocodeGiovannidiDongiovanni
item.content:encoded:
Chères amies, chers amis, permettez-moi de vous présenter la prochaine journées d'études internationales de Phraséologie et parémiologie qui aura lieu à Cagliari les 17 et 18 septembre 2015. item.title: There are some interesting analysis happening in the first practical activity 1.26 in #corpusmooc .
item.dc:creator: MuraNava
item.content:encoded: There are some interesting analysis happening in the first practical activity 1.26 in #corpusmooc . I used the Lextutor Text Compare feature (http://www.lextutor.ca/text_lex_compare/) and screenshotted the first 30 odd results. (I combined corpus files using command line cat and copy pasted into lextutor text compare). You can see immediately differences in proper nouns - names and places between the Brown corpus and the LOB corpus. Common noun differences also appear - e.g. gyro in Brown, grid in LOB. There are also some artifacts e.g. pc in LOB only appears once when using antconc and not 38 times as in screenshot. The word number seems to be an artifact as well since there are about the same in Brown as in LOB.
item.excerpt:encoded: There are some interesting analysis happening in the first practical activity 1.26 in #corpusmooc .

item.title: #corpusmooc 1.23 Laurence Anthony near end of video types in a #regex command but it is not really visible...
item.dc:creator: MuraNava
item.content:encoded: #corpusmooc 1.23 Laurence Anthony near end of video types in a #regex command but it is not really visible (unless you really squint and listen as I did!). I think the command is \br[a-z]*?t\b \b - is beginning of word boundary r - is start character of word [a-z] - means any letter from a to z * - zero or more characters ? - non greedy search (not sure what this means) t- end character of word \b - is end of word boundary So the above will find all words beginning with r and ending with t. update - you can switch to HD view in video player settings, doh!
item.excerpt:encoded: #corpusmooc 1.23 Laurence Anthony near end of video types in a #regex command but it is not really visible...

item.title: corpusmooc 2014 round 1 blogs
item.dc:creator: MuraNava
item.content:encoded: corpusmooc 2014 round 1 blogs A couple of Some blog posts on #corpusmooc have appeared, check them out and if you know of others do post here: one by aProfessor Moravec http://historyinthecity.blogspot.fr/2014/01/moocing-in-public.html and one by Carol Goodey http://cgoodey.wordpress.com/2014/01/28/this-is-not-just-any-mooc/ A post by  Patrick Andrews  http://patrickdandrews.blogspot.co.uk/2014/01/initial-impressions-of-corpus.html that highlights the differences between #corpusmooc and an online learning environment like the Open University. I would agree that the question of moocs for educating the young is limited, there are much greater benefits for professional development. Michael Harrison has posted first impressions of #corpusmooc http://www.mikejharrison.com/2014/01/corpusmooc-corpus-linguistics-week-1/?utm_source=rss&utm_medium=rss&utm_campaign=corpusmooc-corpus-linguistics-week-1 a post by PhD student Julie Voce ‏@julievoce http://julievoce.wordpress.com/2014/02/01/week-1-corpus-linguistics-mooc-with-futurelearn/ a week2 post by Michael Harrison http://www.mikejharrison.com/2014/02/corpusmooc-week-2-struggling-to-keep-up/ - mike i would jump to week 4 for corpus building (and all of the #antconc videos) and some of week 6 and all of week 7 for language learning. Carol Goodey has added another entry answering some common concerns about completing a mooc - http://cgoodey.wordpress.com/2014/02/10/moocing-and-learning-corpora-concordancing-and-conversations/ Sam Shepherd has written about some limits of the FutureLearn setup i.e. discussion forums and getting lost in them - http://samuelshep.wordpress.com/2014/02/13/corpusmooc/. A couple of ways round this is to follow people and filter by their names another is to use this activity feed https://www.futurelearn.com/courses/corpus-linguistics/activity-feed. Of course a further way is to bring in your discussion to this community :) so do post any questions/thoughts here Sam :) a week 3 post by Julie Voce ‏@julievoce noting the difficulties with the commenting system http://julievoce.wordpress.com/2014/02/15/week-3-compare-and-contrast-corpus-linguistics-mooc/ ‏ a post by TeacherPants http://joannalw.wordpress.com/2014/02/18/uninformed-voice-from-the-back-of-the-room-part-i-teacherpants-goes-to-class-virtually/ questioning how to make sense of the data from corpus searches Ann Priestley ‏@annindk is posting her thoughts here https://www.dropbox.com/sh/g7u7ccijtkld6ks/29czNc405q and here - http://myloscar.wordpress.com/tag/corpusmooc/ Mary Carr ‏@marymcarr1 has written some thoughts http://appliedlinguisticsandtesol.blogspot.co.uk/2014/02/corpus-mooc-week-1.html, apparently not a Chomsky fan. Patrick Andrews shares some of his thoughts on one of the readings in #corpusmooc http://patrickdandrews.blogspot.co.uk/2014/03/corpus-mooc-continued-chapter-by-paul.html really nice week6 musings from aProfessor Moravec on looking at -ly adverbs http://historyinthecity.blogspot.fr/2014/01/moocing-in-public.html end of course thoughts by Duygu Çandarlı ‏@duygucandarli http://duygucandarli.wordpress.com/2014/03/24/corpusmooc/ and Karen Carlson ‏@sloopie72 http://sloopie72.wordpress.com/2014/03/25/moocing-corpus-linguistics-futurelearn/ [embed]http://cgoodey.wordpress.com/2014/01/28/this-is-not-just-any-mooc[/embed]

item.title: Formatting wordlists for AntConc
item.dc:creator: MuraNava
item.content:encoded: Formatting wordlists for AntConc #AntConc   needs #wordlists in the order rank, frequency, word but most wordlists you can find on the net are in the order rank, word, frequency. I have tried using Excel to change the columns around but with big wordlists that takes a while! What is even simpler is to use command line, if you are on Windows you can download #Cygwin http://www.cygwin.com/ to get #command line tools. I am using OSX which already has such tools. The command you need is: awk - F'[\t| ]' '{print $1,$3,$2}' OFS="\t" frequency_list_BE06.txt > AntConcBE06List.txt - the - F switch tells awk to look at tabs (\t) or spaces (note the hypen should have no space between it and the letter F, G+ now seems to use hypen as strikethrough markup!) - the print command says to swap column 2 with column 3 - the OFS command tells to output file in tab form - frequency_listBE06 is my input wordlist - AntConcBE06List is my new AntConc friendly word list Note that before loading the new reference wordlist you also need to set the TokenDefinitions in Global Settings in AntConc by ticking all the boxes there i.e. Letter, Number, Punctuation, Symbol, Mark
item.excerpt:encoded: Formatting wordlists for AntConc

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: In the next version of AntConc, I'll add some logic so that rank-word- frequency lists will also be read without change.
great news :)

welcome to the strange world of regular expressions and command line :)
try it out, report back and people here can help
luckily though in future version of AntConc won't need to do this

you need to change into the directory of where u downloaded the word list, one way is to right click the relevant folder and choose New Terminal at Folder. (should be last option in dropdown)
you will then be in a terminal which is in your relevant word list folder, then follow the command replacing the first filenames (frequency_list_BE06.txt in my example) with name in your folder and calling the second filenname (AntConcBE06List.txt) whatever u think fit.
let me how u get on

item.title: UCREL semantic tagger
item.dc:creator: MuraNava
item.content:encoded: UCREL semantic tagger #corpusmooc introduced me to the #UCREL #semantic tagger which you can find here http://ucrel.lancs.ac.uk/usas/ i apologize in advanced for bringing a #sugatamitra related post but hear me out! i thought the #iatefl   mitra debates would be a nice way to get to know about semantic tagging. so i ran the texts i collected on Wednesday 09 April from the net (note i only did a minimal of cleaning up text, so  some duplicates for example are in my current corpus) through the #lancaster tagger. note also i have texts divided into original blog posts and texts of comments to the blog posts. the graphic you see are from the comments to the blog posts and is a way for me to get my head around what could be likely concordances to investigate manually - the words in brackets in the figure labels are potential keywords, the ~ sign represents the most interesting collocation. let me know what you think, is this a good way to pre-analyse a semantically tagged corpus or not?
item.excerpt:encoded: UCREL semantic tagger

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: I've never really done much to go beyond playing with semantic taggers to see how they work, so I can't give any feedback, sorry. Look forward to seeing what others say. But out of interest, where would you go from here and what would you expect to get out of it?

hi Amy Brown great to see you here :) well i would try to use prominent or interesting semantic tags to explore the corpus
so in the chart i have the evaluation category A5 and the good/bad keywords collocate with teachers for example, i did not think to look for collocates of teachers (which is the top keyword in this corpus)!
maybe this reflects my inexperience! the semantic categories certainly help to categorise for me what may be things to look at more closely than just using keywords?

Noor Adnan ‏@n00rbaizura kindly shared her experience using semantic tagging  (she is not G+ member , yet so she had to post it in the following form): https://twitter.com/n00rbaizura/status/455523734162399232/photo/1/large
Here I am! :-)
hi brill :) do let us know when u get your article published, any chance of a preview? :)

Hi,
I'll let you know once my supervisor approves it. In the meantime, let's explore USAS together! I believe there are many more features I haven't discovered. Keep us posted!
Noor
Mura, thanks for explaining. Was interesting to see what Noor said. Put another perspective on things, didn't it?
Noor Baizura Adnan thanks noor be helpful for sure to share experiences of semantic tagging here
Amy Brown certainly looks like Noor's work will be very helpful in this area :)

I sure hope so. Are both of you Lancaster Uni students? My Wmatrix account was canceled a few months ago as I applied for a trial under my supervisor's name for my dissertation. Have to wait till I meet my supervisor to upload more texts. She's an alumni so she has a valid licence. Can't wait!
hi noor no i am not a lancaster student unless being on #corpusmooc counts :)
I didn't get to explore #corpusmooc entirely because of time constraint. My fault, really, I missed so many wonderful things. :-(
Noor Baizura Adnan not to worry as #corpusmooc runs again in Sept :)

I am not a Lancaster student either. I am at the Open University. I was on the MOOC though. You should definitely give it a go if you have time in September. There is lots of content (or there was this time) for everyone from beginner to advanced.
Yup...I was like "Thank god for replay!" or something like that. haha

adding some info here for #corpusmooc round 2 participant about how to create the graphs, it is very simple just select the columns and select the Charts tab and pick a chart! i attach here my Mitra results so that you can save some time from entering the semantic categories by copy pasting from my sheet https://googledrive.com/host/0B7FW2BYaBgeiZ3UyYTByLTdYanc/mitra-semantic-results.xlsx

item.title: #corpusmooc round 2 is about warming up to kick off on September 29
item.dc:creator: MuraNava
item.content:encoded: #corpusmooc round 2 is about warming up to kick off on September 29 i am hoping to get some pre-course info, hint hint Federica Formato :), for you before the start in the meantime here is what i think is the first post in the new cycle by  Kathy Fagan @eslkathy which lists resources highly recommended by yours truly as well http://freerangekef.blogspot.fr/2014/09/join-me.html
item.excerpt:encoded: #corpusmooc round 2 is about warming up to kick off on September 29

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: I am intrigued by your curiosity, Mura :) but who works for the #CorpusMOOC has no secret, everything is almost ready and - just like the other time - you will have an amazing team of researchers in Corpus Linguistics who dedicated their time for you. And I went further, this is not just a hint, this is what it is :P We look forward to starting and meeting you all in couple of weeks!
hi Federica great stuff thx, i was referring to the questions i sent you a few weeks back?

first bit of news direct from #corpusmooc   course leader Tony McEnery on twitter is that a  "lovely reading on data driven learning by Tim Johns to wk 7 the course" is being included  - https://twitter.com/TonyMcEnery/status/510355507136454656 DDL is data-driven learning or diddle/doddle as coined by John Higgins (http://myweb.tiscali.co.uk/wordscape/wordlist/fuelforlearning.html)

There will be new material, it will be made available during the MOOC. At the moment we are working hard to make this an enjoyable and pleasant experience for who wants to learn about corpus linguistics and for who wants to return after the first MOOC. It's just matter of few weeks and you will be able to see yourself what we are working on. Our priority is very simple: give you the best training in the subject, I think this is the only thing worth saying. Whoever is interested is very welcome to sign up for free at this address https://www.futurelearn.com/courses/corpus-linguistics-2014-q3 :) For news and insiders' view, please follow Prof Tony McEnery on Twitter (@TonyMcEnery). I, the team leader, and a team of other mentors will be ready to help during the MOOC.
thanks Federica. do you know if the forum system has been modified at all on the #futurelearn platform? as a lot of people before found it unwieldy?

item.title: Prize Draw corpusmooc 2015 round 3
item.dc:creator: MuraNava
item.content:encoded: Prize Draw corpusmooc 2015 round 3 To mark the third round of #corpusmooc by Lancaster university which starts on 28 September 2015,  the G+ CL Community is putting up a prize draw for the book Discovering English with SketchEngine by James Thomas . To enter you should be enrolled on #corpusmooc and answer the following question: According to the BYU-COCA interface what is the 9th most common adjective that goes with the noun prize? Use the default window size of 4 words to left and 4 words to right. In the case of a tie there will be a qualifying question. Post your answers in this thread. Postage will be included in prize. To find out a bit about the book have a read of this - https://eflnotes.wordpress.com/2015/06/14/discovering-english-with-sketchengine-james-thomas-interview/ *Note this prize draw is not officially associated with the #corpusmooc or Lancaster University.* Good Luck!
item.excerpt:encoded: Prize Draw corpusmooc 2015 round 3

item.title: CorpusMooc 2016 round 4 Blog Posts
item.dc:creator: MuraNava
item.content:encoded: CorpusMooc 2016 round 4 Blog Posts CorpusMooc 2016 has kicked off and time to collect participants blog posts : ) First one on the radar is by Marc Jones #CorpusMOOC Week 1 notes [https://freelanceteacherselfdevelopment.wordpress.com/2016/09/27/corpusmooc-week-1-notes/] Marc asks if certain frequent language items are acquired later rather than earlier. No doubt, and not easy to answer but an important point is raised that we can't solely depend on frequency when deciding what to teach based on corpus descriptions. Michael Brown describes his experience of Week 1 of #corpusmooc - [https://corpling4efl.wordpress.com/2016/10/03/corpusmooc-week-1/] Vedrana Vojkovic Estatiev  who did the mooc in 2014 reflects on changes [https://afteroctopus.wordpress.com/2016/10/06/corpusmooc-take-two/] Marc Jones gets down to week 2 musings [https://educationechochamberuncut.wordpress.com/2016/10/07/corpusmooc-week-2-marc/] Michael Brown reports his week 2 experiences [https://corpling4efl.wordpress.com/2016/10/10/corpusmooc-week-2/] Michael Brown talks about week 3 [https://corpling4efl.wordpress.com/2016/10/15/corpusmooc-week-3/] Michael Brown gives his lowdown on weeks 4 and 5 [https://corpling4efl.wordpress.com/2016/10/26/corpusmooc-weeks-4-5/] Michael Brown reports on weeks 6 and 7 [https://corpling4efl.wordpress.com/2016/11/13/corpusmooc-weeks-6-7/] Final blog by Michael Brown on week 8 [https://corpling4efl.wordpress.com/2016/11/28/corpusmooc-week-8/] If you look in the #corpusmooc section you can read previous iterations of mooc participants thoughts on the course.

item.title: Corpusmooc 2016 round 4 aids
item.dc:creator: MuraNava
item.content:encoded: Corpusmooc 2016 round 4 aids Here I will occasionally put up helpers/explainers/aids related to queries people have had on the #corpusmooc . For example there were a number of questions about collocation statistics so I knocked up a chart based on a video and one of the readings - Identifying Collocations [https://magic.piktochart.com/output/16856740-identify_collocations] I did some similar charts for previous corpusmoocs you can look up in the corpusmooc section. Another set of queries was about distinguishing collocations from colligations (see previous corpusmooc for a related chart), this time round found a nice example from John Sinclair: For example, the English letter string second can be claimed to have two primary meanings based on results of a collocation analysis: (i) ‘next to the first’ when it is used together with words such as the, world, war, year, child and wife, and (ii) ‘a unit of time’ when it is preceded by words such as per, radians and cycles. In addition to being attracted to different lexical contexts, the two primary meanings of second also prefer different grammatical contexts: second as ‘next to the first’ is often a part of a definite noun phrase, while second as ‘a unit of time’ can be usually found in an indefinite noun phrase (Sinclair 1991: 107). Hence, the collocational preferences of the two senses correlate with the colligational preferences. which was cited in the following pdf - [http://pubman.mpdl.mpg.de/pubman/item/escidoc:2304786:2/component/escidoc:2304785/Collocation%20and%20colligation.pdf] Hope these are of use : ) [embed]https://magic.piktochart.com/output/16856740-identify_collocations[/embed]
item.excerpt:encoded: Corpusmooc 2016 round 4 aids

item.title: When is Open not open? FutureLearn MOCS
item.dc:creator: MuraNava
item.content:encoded: When is Open not open? FutureLearn MOCS The new #corpusmooc seems to be time-limited (8 weeks + 14 days) unless you cough up 34(+shipping) Euros. Reading up on the FutureLearn site they state that: "it is therefore for partners to determine the appropriate licensing for this course content." I noticed a number of courses have been doing this recently so it seems to be a default position encouraged by FutureLearn? Has Lancaster University actively agreed to this or simply going along with such a default position? Some impact is mitigated by the public access made by Lancaster Uni to taxpayer supported material such as #lancsbox (concordancer software). I don't want to come across too much as, what some people disparagingly call, a "freetard" and the economics of running online education has many challenges. However, this FutureLearn position certainly jars up against the original philosophies of MOOCS - massive OPEN online course. Time to look to alternative linguistic MOOCS? such as Virtual Linguistic Campus [https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCaMpov1PPVXGcKYgwHjXB3g] See also: Other noteworthy developments in #corpusmooc [https://plus.google.com/u/0/+MuraNava/posts/foVTzqTF9a1]

item.title: BootCat Seeding
item.dc:creator: MuraNava
item.content:encoded: BootCat Seeding There could be some disappointment with #corpusmooc week 4 billed as building your own corpus. The lectures are more of a general discussion of corpus building along with very useful lectures on the CLAWS part of speech tagging and USAS semantic tagging. In my opinon a section on the web as a corpus would have been good. For example the use of #BootCat . You can read about how to use BootCat here - http://bootcat.sslmit.unibo.it/?section=home. What I would like to note is the process of finding good seed words. How BootCat works is this: 1.seed (words) - e.g. you can use keywords derived from comparing a sample corpus (that you build manually) to a reference corpus 2. tuples - the seed words are combined, default is three so for example if seeds are one, two, three, four, five (you need min of 5 seed words); a tuple could be one, two, four , default no. of tuples is 10 3. collect urls - collect urls that contain these tuples, you need to go through this carefully to ensure the text is what you want; BootCat helpfully links to the urls for you to check but of course if you have a lot of URLs it is a time consuming process; you can alleviate this somewhat by specifying domains to leave out of the url collection stage 4. build corpus - build corpus with the collected urls If you are not satisfied with the resulting corpus you can redo BootCat process using say keywords and/or n-grams from the (unsatisfying) corpus to build a new BootCat corpus. You can of course keep repeating this. When I was looking to build web design related corpora the results I was getting were disappointing. Then I hit upon the idea of using already existing categories from A List Apart, a well known site for web designers. They have a topics section, so for example one of their top level topics of Design includes Brand Identity, Graphic Design, Layout & Grids, Mobile/Multidevice, Responsive Design,Typography & Web Fonts. So I used these as seed words and the resulting corpus was much better, I intend to do a similar approach to build corpora reflecting two other A List Apart top level topics of Code and User Experience. Apparently there is a new version of BootCat coming with some neat new features. FYI if you already have a website that you want to collect texts from have a read of my post here - http://eflnotes.wordpress.com/2013/03/06/building-your-own-corpus-textstat-antconc/ see also - BootCat Custom URL [https://eflnotes.wordpress.com/2014/10/08/building-your-own-corpus-bootcat/] [embed]http://bootcat.sslmit.unibo.it/?section=home[/embed]
item.excerpt:encoded: BootCat Seeding

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: for anyone interested you can get hold of a copy of the beta version 0.72 here http://bootcat.sslmit.unibo.it/download/devel/BootCaT_front.zip you need java 7 and do note that this is still beta quick impression after testing the new url download feature is that the text cleanup seems better apparently the developers have used a new procedure for this

Hi Mura, I agree with you. I have known Bootcat since four years ago but still confused with choosing seed words so that we could minimize duplicated text to retrieve. Glad you brought this program up.

Gede Primahadi Wijaya R. hi the beta is really good now with the new url only feature; boot cat is on its way to becoming very very useful, though not sure about the future of web as a corpus with say accelerating privatization of the open net?!
how are you finding the #corpusmooc so far?
Hi Mura, Thanks for the response. Url only? That sounds awesome. I've got to check that out really soon. Thanks a lot.

i think if you use examples from the publications, you cite them otherwise i don't know, maybe people like Laurence Anthony or Amy Brown or Noor Baizura Adnan or Federica Formato can help?

Ideally, yes. Minimally, the readers should be able to access this sort of information, e.g., via a link to details of the corpus on your website.
Laurence.
Thank you so much.

item.title: Mathematicians at the University of Vermont have analyzed corpora of ten languages and concluded that human...
item.dc:creator: KateStone
item.content:encoded:
Mathematicians at the University of Vermont have analyzed corpora of ten languages and concluded that human languages appear to have a surprisingly positive bias. Rather nice chart included.
[embed]http://ehscience.co/2015/02/11/global-preference-positive-happy-words[/embed]
item.excerpt:encoded: Mathematicians at the University of Vermont have analyzed corpora of ten languages and concluded that human...

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: thxs and welcome to community Kate :) it's interesting no linguists involved in study e.g. "words - the atoms of human language" what about morphemes? what about multi-words? sentiment ratings on a single word will miss out how it is used with other words etc here's a link to their interesting tool http://hedonometer.org/books.html

Mura Nava I'm not surprised, considering the many mathematicians, computer scientists, and psychologists who have tried their hands at applied and theoretical linguistics over the decades. :) That said, it would be interesting to see if a study of the same data, done in collaboration with linguists, would result in the same findings. Thanks for the welcome!
a linguist takes down paper here http://andreadallover.com/2015/03/01/if-youre-not-a-linguist-dont-do-linguistic-research

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: hi there Emin thanks for the question; not sure what you mean by "graded" corpora? what kind of thing would you like to use the corpora for?

By graded I mean corpora with simplified texts (as it is the case with graded readers) to suit Intermediate & Upper-Intermediate level of students. It is frequently mentioned in the literature that EFL learners find BNC hard to work with due to its advanced language level. Some researchers use the semester materials to make their own corpus for research purposes with their students. So, I was wondering whether there are any corpora with the above-mentioned level. I hope I was clear this time. :)

okay there may be something here [https://plus.google.com/+MuraNava/posts/CWQdHv7dzHm] let me know if that helps plus.google.com - Apparently there is a section in COCA-BYU Fiction called Juvenile. This can b...
Thank you!
No problem 😀

item.title: Hi there!
item.dc:creator: MaryPerez
item.content:encoded:
Hi there! I'm a current MA student in Durham University, new to the community, and looking for advice on what areas of research I could delve into using corpora. I've been interested in corpora since last term and have to hand in a dissertation proposal next week.
I was wondering if it might be worth looking into the language presented in coursebooks and comparing them with corpora data to see if the coursebook language is representative of language that is actually used.
OR if it might be more useful to work on a learner's corpora here at the university based off of international students' texts to help analyse supposed written errors . Perhaps this could provide a look into whether common errors are made or if what looks like errors are really just a different word choices that represent the writer's perceptions?
Basically I was hoping to use corpora in my research but haven't been able to really narrow it down to a research question and don't want to go into something that has been overly researched already. Any feedback or advice would be greatly appreciated!
item.excerpt:encoded: Hi there!

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: hi Mary welcome, what is your MA in? i am sure some people here could help, you could also try posting on the Facebook CL group and/or Corpora List (see links in About section) Ramesh Krishnamurthy on the Facebook group is very helpful but you may want to have a clearer idea of what you want to do? imo learner corpora are really interesting, i know Diane Nicholls is into these maybe she could help out? she also has a series of posts on open access learner corpora maybe reading those may spark some ideas? e.g. post 1 - http://learnercorpus.blogspot.fr/2014/02/openly-available-learner-corpora-1.html?spref=tw good luck!

Thank you for the suggestions Mura Nava. I guess that's part of my problema, feeling like corpora could be used for a wide range of research but not exactly sure where to go but I'll have to delve more into some more readings I guess.

item.title: I want to package a small corpus I made and let students make concordances with it.
item.dc:creator: AnthonySchmidt
item.content:encoded: I want to package a small corpus I made and let students make concordances with it. Is there a web-based concordancer I can install on my website that would give them access to the corpus?
item.excerpt:encoded: I want to package a small corpus I made and let students make concordances with it.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: hi anthony, interesting question i think it depends on your admin skills e.g. most comprehensive is open corpus workbench http://cwb.sourceforge.net there is also #nosketchengine http://nlp.fi.muni.cz/trac/noske another simpler perl one is this http://sourceforge.net/projects/perlconc/ which u can see running here http://lists.bilkent.edu.tr/~robin/cgibin/concord.cgi there are some related tools  here e.g. student text upload and vocab comparer http://robin.bilkent.edu.tr/computers.html Robin Turner  is on G+ guess he could help with Q's? otherwise i guess you could rely on Lextutor and Flax (http://flax.nzdl.org/greenstone3/flax) which allows you to upload texts but not be able to use on your own server do keep community posted with any developments
Thanks for all the resources. I'll start off with Perlconc since I do not have a private web server. Unfortunately, I've already run into problems with it and I'm hoping Robin Turner can help.
hi i d/l program to test and am getting "Internal Server Error" was this error you were getting Anthony Schmidt ?
Yes. I got a white page with a 500 server error in the source.
hi anthony any progress?
Not yet. Some of the other programs you mentioned would be great, but I don't have the required level of access on my server. I wish I was better at python.
did you try contacting robin? i'll try to have another look this weekend

item.title: A snapshot of how I work with #concordances :
item.dc:creator: MuraNava
item.content:encoded: A snapshot of how I work with #concordances : I am currently trying to set-up a quick exercise on #multimedia   related words. I have my corpus loaded in AntConc. The cleaned-up corpus admittedly took me a few hours to set-up (I may detail that sometime). So now I have just run the keyword list function and am picking out some relevant words. For example blog scores highly and so I looked at the concordances of blog. I then sort the concordance lines one word to the left and see that the patterns with blog fall into 3 groups, possesive pronoun - my blog; with article - a blog; and as verb - I blog. (I attach the sorted concordance lines for blog). I am now going through those groups to pick out some suitable ones where the surrounding words are appropriate to my students. I will then use these sentences in a gap fill asking students to find the missing word. I'll repeat this for other relevant/interesting multi-media words. Let me know if you have any questions.
item.excerpt:encoded: A snapshot of how I work with #concordances :

item.title: Wrangling regular expressions and commandeering the command line
item.dc:creator: MuraNava
item.content:encoded: Wrangling regular expressions and commandeering the command line At some point when dealing with texts you will have to use the #commandline   and #regularexpressions   as it makes life much easier, although of course there is a steep learning curve. Needs must and I recently bit the bullet and did my first #regex commands. I am working with text from The Setup http://usesthis.com/ - a series of interviews which poses 4 simple questions about the equipment setup that people use in their work. Now this website is great not only for the interesting interviews but for the fact that since the project is hosted on github one can very easily have a copy of all the interviews (i.e. you need a github account, then you can copy(fork) the project and download files). Once you have the text files they need a little cleaning since the words which are linked are given in square brackets and the http link is put into round brackets e.g. : I'm [Alex Payne](http://al3x.net/ "Alex's website."). I go by [al3x](http://twitter.com/al3x "Alex's Twitter account.") around the Interwho. I work at [Twitter](http://twitter.com/ "Micro-blogging FTW.") in San Francisco as their [API](http://apiwiki.twitter.com/ "The Twitter API Wiki.") Lead. I want to remove only the square brackets [ ] and everything between the round brackets, including the round brackets. A command for removing only the square brackets using the #sed   command is: sed -i.bak 's/[ ] [ ]//g' file.txt The -i.bak is really two commands the -i means replace the original file with the results of the sed program (keeping both the unmatched text and the matched text) and .bak means make a backup of the original file. The 's/[ ][ ]//g' is the interesting part as this contains the regular expression. The normal structure of the substitute sed s command is 's/regex/replacement/g' In this case the characters I want is [ and ], but since [ is already a command i.e. [abc] will match a or b or c,  you can put the closing square bracket first and then the opening square bracket i.e. [ ] [ ] will match ] or [ which is the same as matching [ or ]. The replacement is simply a blank. The g means match all occurences of the regex pattern. Now I want to delete the round brackets and everything in between the round brackets the command is : sed -i.bak2 's/([^( )]*)//g' file.txt Notice I called the new backup bak2 so I can distinguish easily between the results of the two commands. It is possible to combine commands but not figured that out yet! The regex looks for the opening bracket (. Then anything between that is not an opening bracket or close bracket, the caret ^ means not the following character i.e. not ( or ). The star means match zero or more of such characters which are not an opening bracket or closing bracket. Then finally match a closing bracket ). Not sure how useful my particular example will be to people here but I wanted to highlight the fact that understanding regular expressions and using the command line saves a lot of time. For example at the time of writing this there are 395 interview files, imagine having to open them up in a text editor and doing find and replace! In the command line it is a simple case of using unix wildstar on the text, in my case 2*.txt as the files are labelled year-month-day-nameofinterviewee.txt There are numerous resources on using regex and sed command online; I learnt a bit because I had the need not to go through 395 text files! Thanks for reading. Questions welcome. [embed]http://usesthis.com/[/embed]
item.excerpt:encoded: Wrangling regular expressions and commandeering the command line

item.title: Question1a: For US English, does core collocate more as a noun or as a verb with apple(s)?
item.dc:creator: MuraNava
item.content:encoded: Question1a: For US English, does core collocate more as a noun or as a verb with apple(s)? Question1b: How about for British English? Question1c: And what about historical US English? Note all the above can be done using BYU COCA interface. Inspired by a Andrew Walkley blog post on frequent word core http://blog.westminster.ac.uk/celt/2013/10/23/core/ [embed]http://blog.westminster.ac.uk/celt/2013/10/23/core/[/embed]
item.excerpt:encoded: Question1a: For US English, does core collocate more as a noun or as a verb with apple(s)?

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: well as no-one has responded to this, i'll do so :) 1a)in COCA core seems to collocate with apple more as a verb than as a noun - http://corpus.byu.edu/coca/?c=coca&q=27368385 - you'll need to drill down into apple collocates 1b) in BNC core collocates more as a noun with apple - http://corpus.byu.edu/bnc/?c=bnc&q=27368449 comparing COCA with BNC seems to confirm this - http://corpus.byu.edu/coca/?c=coca&q=27368217&q1=27368265 1c) historically around 1990 core as a verb/adjective generally seems to have been increasing in use and in COHA seems to dominate the collocation with apple do you agree?

If you want to find out the search sequence the writer used check my post here: http://eflnotes.wordpress.com/2013/02/22/quick-cup-of-coca-quantifierdeterminer-preposition-relative-pronoun/ [embed]http://literalminded.wordpress.com/2013/11/08/all-of-which/[/embed]

item.title: A common problem with using #corpora like #COCA is the amount of surrounding words that can cause problems for...
item.dc:creator: MuraNava
item.content:encoded: A common problem with using #corpora like #COCA is the amount of surrounding words that can cause problems for students; of course one way around that is to choose carefully the concordances and/or modify them. Another route is to use a #gradedreader #corpus ,the lextutor site provides some graded readers here http://www.lextutor.ca/conc/graded/. They total to about 1.3 million words so not a shabby corpus size. :) The lextutor graded reader interface doesn't allow wildcard searches (though you could use the main lextutor concordancer), downloading files and using #antconc will give you more options and control. You can of course copy paste/download each file by hand but a much quicker way is to use the wget command (this is standard on Linux and OSX and separate download available for Windows). In a terminal first build a file of the URLs from the graded reader site: cat > listofurls.txt Then run: wget -i listofurls.txt If you are not familiar/comfortable with running command lines let me know to get a copy of the texts. So for example I was looking for sentences with the word contract (for my TOEIC class). As you can see from the 1st screenshot the word contract comes from a level 5 text which is B2 or upper intermediate; this still produces a relatively “simple” sentence  with some nice collocations e.g.  In our business, contracts are made and cancelled routinely. With less specialized items you can get more range of levels e.g. advice (the 2nd screenshot): a level 3 text gives - She always gave us good advice. A graded reader corpus is also a way for students to get into concordances; for some info on whether a graded corpus is ‘authentic’ see "Can a graded reader corpus provide ‘authentic’ input?" by Rachel Allan (2008) https://drive.google.com/file/d/0B7FW2BYaBgeiVmxpeGlyNk5EWmc/edit?usp=sharing Related - COCA-BYU's Fiction-Juvenile section [https://plus.google.com/+MuraNava/posts/CWQdHv7dzHm]
item.excerpt:encoded: A common problem with using #corpora like #COCA is the amount of surrounding words that can cause problems for...

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
Thank you Mura for posting this. I actually came upon it when you linked it to a later post.
I too have been wrestling with the "accessibility" of corpora particularly with lower level learners.
On one hand I thought it was an issue of training ( i.e. how to look at concordances) that was the issue but this post reminds me that the content must also be comprehensible.
Definitely food for thought.....
a pleasure Peter :)

item.title: An idea to use very short scenes from films as a way to #teach #corpus use #literacy .
item.dc:creator: MuraNava
item.content:encoded: An idea to use very short scenes from films as a way to #teach   #corpus use #literacy . A #dialogue from the latest Hobbit movie features the word jiffy. Ask students to listen to the scene and transcribe the dialogue. After some listens they may get the following: Thorin: Balin, can you still mix a flash flame? Balin: Aye, it’ll only take a jiffy, c’mon Dwalin: We don’t have a jiffy. Ask students what they think jiffy means? Then ask them to go to #COCA and enter the following search: it 'll only take a * they should get the following: IT 'LL ONLY TAKE A MINUTE IT 'LL ONLY TAKE A SECOND IT 'LL ONLY TAKE A FEW IT 'LL ONLY TAKE A MOMENT IT 'LL ONLY TAKE A COUPLE ask them what kind of word they see in the list; ask them to click on few and couple to see what follows them; then see if it holds true for the following search: it will only take a * additionally tell students: 1)that an asterisk represents any single word, ask them to add another asterisk to first search term 2)punctuation marks need to include a space when they are in the search term 3)to combine both ‘ll and will in one search use the pipe character | (http://corpus.byu.edu/coca/?c=coca&q=27583618) [embed]http://corpus.byu.edu/coca/?c=coca&q=27583632[/embed]
item.excerpt:encoded: An idea to use very short scenes from films as a way to #teach #corpus use #literacy .

item.title: I would suggest , even though I have no evidence, that open access corpora such as #BYU #COCA have...
item.dc:creator: MuraNava
item.content:encoded: I would suggest , even though I have no evidence, that open access corpora such as #BYU #COCA have single-handedly done more to encourage corpus use than anything else in recent times. As members of this community I would think that we would want to see this kind of development. If something is made a commons people make use of it and who knows what opportunities have been lost to closed off corpora. So it was with interest I saw a tweet that #cambridgeuniversity Press  are looking to build a new spoken corpus (http://www.networxrecruitment.com/Jobs/Advert/46522?FromSearch=False). I enquired as to whether this corpus would be open to the public, their answer : No, I'm afraid out Cambridge English Corpus is only for use by Cambridge University Press. Notice the typo, out for our; so this is our corpus because we transacted with you for a set price (18pounds) and now that commodity is our property that you can’t access unless you transact with us for another set price (?pounds). Unfortunately the same holds true for other tax-payer funded academic institutions where for example learner corpora are under pay licenses. Do we need to co-operate with such practices? Are there possibilities to agitate for change? Do you disagree with me? Hmm well that did not turn into too much of a rant. Here’s the email to the corpus project if you feel like enquiring yourself: corpus@cambridge.org [embed]http://www.networxrecruitment.com/Jobs/Advert/46522?FromSearch=False[/embed]
item.excerpt:encoded: I would suggest , even though I have no evidence, that open access corpora such as #BYU #COCA have...

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Hi Mura, I'm as eager as you are to see more open-access corpora, in particular, learner corpora, but (without wishing to sound like an apologist for CUP) the corpora CUP spend huge amounts of money collecting and building provide them with a valuable USP for their ELT publications. If they made them publicly available, they would be giving away a huge competitive edge in their very competitive market and would lose that USP completely. Why would they invest so much in something just to give it away? Would anyone expect them to give away the books they publish based on their corpora? When you say this: "so this is our corpus because we transacted with you for a set price (18pounds) and now that commodity is our property that you can’t access unless you transact with us for another set price (?pounds)." - I think that's a bit misleading. Their corpora are not and never have been for sale to anyone (as far as I know). There are learner corpora people can pay for access to if they can afford it, (and I share your frustration with that) but CUP's aren't among them. I think we will see more and more freely available corpora and I share your impatience for the day.

hi diane
thanks for commenting, and i see your points.
i wonder in fact how much they actually spend on building corpora? and who does that? the USP surely comes from how CUP analyses the data not the data itself?
in anycase i think these issues are not as important as the fact that CUP trades off the name of Cambridge University which is publicly funded. there's no getting around that issue and i acknowledge that change may come and why not help move that along by raising the really important issue of open access in our tax-payer funded institutions?
ta mura

item.title: There is a nice list of ways of #counting written up by one Heather Froehlich ‏@heatherfro.
item.dc:creator: MuraNava
item.content:encoded: There is a nice list of ways of #counting written up by one Heather Froehlich ‏@heatherfro. This is good way to introduce things a computer can do with a corpus before more 'technical' words like #collocation, #clusters etc.: Ways of Counting Words Kinds of words Words with certain features Words without certain features Words that show up a lot Words that show up very rarely Words that are there Words that aren’t there Words that appear more in one set compared to another set Words that appear less in one set compared to another set Words likely to be near other words Words unlikely to be near other words Words that make recognizable phrases Words that do not make recognizable phrases She lists some others which are more suited to a humanities audience as she is a humanities scholar. You can find her slides here:http://hfroehlich.files.wordpress.com/2014/01/northwestern-2014-new-world-of-words.pdf [embed]http://hfroehlich.files.wordpress.com/2014/01/northwestern-2014-new-world-of-words.pdf[/embed]
item.excerpt:encoded: There is a nice list of ways of #counting written up by one Heather Froehlich ‏@heatherfro.

item.title: Dogme and manual concordancing
item.dc:creator: MuraNava
item.content:encoded: Dogme and manual concordancing So I was working 1-to-1with a student on listening to Scottish accents using a recording taken from the International Dialects of English Archive. It was a simple procedure of listening to extracts of the recording a few times to identify what he could, doing a number of micro-listens, then turning to the transcript to check. After this we went through the transcript to look at any interesting lexis. My student noticed that the speaker was using a lot of 'guess'. I had not noticed this as I was still looking for parts related to decoding issues. Whilst we were having a discussion on why the speaker was using guess and how, it struck me to try a manual #concordancing of the word guess from the text. The photo is the result. I explained to the student that we can call this a concordance and that it helps us look at how words work - in this case use of pronoun I, co-occurrence with so, but, and positions at start or middle of sentence. I also took the opportunity to mention http://www.just-the-word.com/ as a way to see more uses of concordances. So I claim this as a use of #dogme concordancing. :) For an interesting read of blackboard concordancing or hand concordancing have a read of this report of two Spanish teachers in France - Corpus work with ordinary teachers: Data-driven learning activities by Henry Tyne - https://www.academia.edu/1474616/Corpus-work_with_ordinary_teachers_Data-driven_learning_activities
item.excerpt:encoded: Dogme and manual concordancing

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Jane Willis pioneered hand concordancing and describes a number of activities using coursebook texts and transcripts in Willis, J. 1998. ‘Concordances in the classroom without a computer: assembling and exploring concordances of common words,’ in Tomlinson, B. (ed.) Materials Development in Language Teaching, New York: Cambridge University Press. (But I love the label 'dogme concordancing'!)
Scott Thornbury thanks Scott great ref! there's a pdf of it here https://drive.google.com/open?id=0B7FW2BYaBgeibzFxaVR4SmhlQzg
Who says concordancing is only for computers?! Brilliant post because there needs to be a great deal of scaffolding involved when introducing data-driven learning to the classroom.
thanks Peter Parise , the reference that Scott gave is really worth checking out if u haven't already

item.title: #Phrasal #verbs duh duh duh!
item.dc:creator: MuraNava
item.content:encoded: #Phrasal #verbs duh duh duh! Strikes real fear in many learners' hearts and trepidation to many teachers - especially what phrasal verbs to teach? One reference I found is - Pointing Out Frequent Phrasal Verbs: A #Corpus -Based Analysis by Dee Gardener & Mark Davies (2007) http://203.72.145.166/tesol/tqd_2008/VOL_41_2.pdf They point out that the four most common adverb particles are out, up, down, back. This can help learners and teachers identify phrasal verbs. They go on to list the 20 most common lexical verbs. The study is based on the British National Corpus (BNC), what if one is looking for say business phrasal verbs? This is where the great #BYU #COCA interface comes in handy, we can easily search by sections. So for example looking at the lexical verb GO ,which is the number one ranked verb in the study, plus the part of speech (POS) adverb particle and choosing MAG(azine):Financial and comparing it to all of the MAGAZINE genre we see GO under as being 5 times more common in MAG:Financial, this holds true when comparing NEWS(paper):Money to NEWSPAPER. http://corpus.byu.edu/coca/?c=coca&q=27962547 Further when comparing MAG:Financial to NEWS:Money we see GO along as being twice as common in MAG:Financial as in NEWS:Money http://corpus.byu.edu/coca/?c=coca&q=27962581 One can do similar searches with the other lexical verbs given in the study. This is a way then to draw up a list of interesting business phrasal verbs. The other problem is then of course how to tackle the different meanings of a phrasal verb?! See also: [https://plus.google.com/+MuraNava/posts/hXPEBYURsKG] [https://plus.google.com/+MuraNava/posts/jgXwYfDRq9Z] [embed]http://203.72.145.166/tesol/tqd_2008/VOL_41_2.pdf[/embed]
item.excerpt:encoded: #Phrasal #verbs duh duh duh!

What happened?...Stopped by the bell :-( Second installement next week LOL

Elizabeth Anne I had the same thing happen when I made a interactive whiteboard from a wiimote for some friends. You have to build it up.
If advanced technology is indistinguishable from magic, perhaps we need to look at how magicians present magic. (PS. If you were, without any visible means, to fly around a shopping mall, I think you get pretty much the same look.)
Your observation, however, has totally inspired me for an opening to a talk. (And a magic trick that mixes Spanish, the periodic elements, and finishes like a Chestertonian essay... I hope.) Will you be at TESOL Spain?
what's your talk on matt?

Now it is about a magic trick that will start everyone's reacting like my friends, and Elizabeth's students, and finishes with an "ah!", I hope.
Really, it's about macro and micro email corpuses without tears at TESOL Spain. (Called "Enron, Little Data, and the infinite monkey machine")
Obviously about Enron email database, and also about changing students sent mail to a (non shared) txt file they can explore with AntConc. (Bonus: I discovered I say "I would love to" waaaay too much.) I am building up a live binder in which the g+ community figures, so I hope it helps with your nerd farming project. ; )
Following, but left speechless already. I already found the video brill. I am ALWAYS telling my elec engineering students about Enron. It is the same one isn't it. (Fat boy, get shorty, etc)?
Matt Ledding woah what a title :) TESOL Spain normaly puts up presentations on their website don't they? look fwd to reading yours, will it be videotaped?

Matt Ledding Noooo I just checked and saw it was THIS weekend. Could you not get someone to hold up an ipad and stream it to us by http://www.ustream.tv/ Heike Philp used to do that all the time from TESOL fr at least, and it worked really well.

Elizabeth Anne will see what I can do... I am busy focusing on my talk not sucking right now. ; )    Here is my work in process on livebinders.  There are a couple of corpora versions of the Enron emails... just straight data, no tagging.  http://www.livebinders.com/play/play?id=1268034   suggestions?  There was a talk on corpus work for beginners with some neat ideas that I remember hearing from Mura, I think...
Matt Ledding were u thinking of this https://docs.google.com/file/d/0B4KeTUgQQhL-MFZDVl9NRXV3V1BnREl6WW9XSDNDcVlTd25B/edit ? conc em out at your talk :)

by the way, on the Enron database: check out page 5: http://comp.social.gatech.edu/papers/cscw12.hierarchy.gilbert.pdf   Neat, huh?
break a leg

item.title: Costas Gabrielatos a linguist from Edge HIll University has kindly answered some questions I posed to him.
item.dc:creator: MuraNava
item.content:encoded: Costas Gabrielatos a linguist from Edge HIll University has kindly answered some questions I posed to him. ---------- 1. Tell us a little about your background.   I started as a language teacher, and then moved to teacher education. Almost from the beginning, I got more interested in the ‘language’ side of ‘language teaching’ – a main contributing reason being the high frequency of overgeneralisations and inaccuracies in the information (‘rules’) provided in coursebooks and pedagogical grammars. This led me to corpus-based linguistics, but with an eye to pedagogical implications. My currently focus, as far as LT is concerned, is on corpus-based pedagogical grammar and analysis of learner language.    2. Why should teachers consider #corpora in their classroom?   I think ‘should’ might be a bit too strong. More to the point, I think encouraging teachers to adopt corpus-based teaching approaches irrespective of their knowledge/skills is simply misguided. Before teachers (or researchers, for that matter) attempt to use corpus-based techniques, they need to have acquired relevant knowledge and skills. I’ve observed enough lessons based on misunderstood notions of ‘communicative teaching’ to shudder at the idea of a hasty adoption of CL techniques in language teaching. However, given the knowledge/skills, then access to corpora can enrich any teaching approach – provided, of course, that the approach does not allow ‘rules’ to trump evidence of actual language use.   3. Why do you think take up of it has been slow if not non-existent?   Lack of knowledge and skills, and perhaps lack of time and/or interest. Another possibility is the perception of corpus-based approaches as rather ‘academic’ (cue in the stereotypical aloof lecturer and lab-coated researcher). In fact, in light of my previous answer, I don’t find the current low level of adoption something to be unhappy about.   4. Do you think that is changing with wider availability of corpus interfaces such as COCA?   Judging from the increasing number of relevant journal papers, conference presentations, discussion groups, and websites/blogs, the interest in the utility of CL techniques for language teaching appears to be rising. However, it seems to me that the increase in interest is not so much on the part of what we might call traditional classroom teachers, but those who teach in universities, or are involved in online language teaching, or are in the process of moving away from the (virtual) classroom and towards academia.   5. Do you know to what extent the Lancaster corpus MOOC would interest teachers?   I can’t tell if it would interest teachers, but I think it offers a very good way in for those considering adding corpus-based elements to their teaching. Not only because there is a component on corpora and language teaching, but also, and more importantly, because the MOOC introduces participants to the core concepts, constructs and techniques in CL.   6. Can you recommend just one reference/resource to help language teachers with corpora?   The short answer is: ‘I refuse to do that’. The longer answer is that I think it is limiting and educationally detrimental to only derive information from a single source. CL is not monolithic, and there are currently a lot of disputes regarding some of its core theoretical notions and analytical approaches – even the very nature of CL is being debated (for example, see https://benjamins.com/#catalog/journals/ijcl.15.3/toc ). My advice would be to read as many introductory chapters/books by different authors as possible and, in typical CL fashion,  try to identify patterns in approaches and practices – keeping in mind that newer introductions are not necessarily better than older ones.   7. Any comments you would like to add not yet covered?   Just a few things I always stress at the beginning of a CL module/seminar: ·      Corpus linguistics is something you learn primarily by doing: working with corpus tools and reflecting critically on both the results you get and the techniques that yielded these results. ·      If you expect the ease and automaticity that would be afforded by a StarTrek-type computer, you’ll be disappointed – CL involves a lot of manual work. ·      Corpus linguistics is very easy to do badly.   For a detailed account of my views on corpora and language teaching, see here: http://tesl-ej.org/ej32/a1.html
item.excerpt:encoded: Costas Gabrielatos a linguist from Edge HIll University has kindly answered some questions I posed to him.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: I've got an account but checked it yesterday and couldn't locate any of the new features listed. It says they're in Beta, so maybe not available to Joe (or Jo) Public yet? Will explore further.
thanks diane

OK. I had a look. You have to access the Beta version via the home page to get these new features. Then you need a login... I had a look but without (error-coded) learner corpora in my personal account, that's as far as I got. I believe I'll have an opportunity to test them next month though. I'll report back.

item.title: #Corpus Linguistics in fiction.
item.dc:creator: MuraNava
item.content:encoded: #Corpus Linguistics in fiction. My wife is reading a #DavidLodge novel called Deaf Sentence (French title - La vie en sourdine) and mentioned to me that there is a passage in the book (bottom of page 232 to top of page 234 - http://books.google.fr/books?id=U2MMEMw9wzIC&lpg=PA234&ots=FBUT0K16Xl&dq=deaf%20sentence%20corpus%20linguistics&pg=PA232#v=onepage&q&f=false) looking at the #collocates of happy and deaf.  Two #corpora are used one of size 1.5 million and one of size 50 million ("the biggest available"). So my question is can anyone figure out the two corpora that are referred to? The novel was published in 2008. [embed]http://books.google.fr/books?id=U2MMEMw9wzIC&lpg=PA234&ots=FBUT0K16Xl&dq=deaf+sentence+corpus+linguistics&pg=PA232#v=onepage&q&f=false[/embed]
item.excerpt:encoded: #Corpus Linguistics in fiction.

item.title: #BNC14 media blitz
item.dc:creator: MuraNava
item.content:encoded: #BNC14 media blitz This post has been cut as requested by Robbie Love. It shows the questions I asked but not the responses as you have to now get information about BNC14 through official channels only. Note added his reflections on the whole media experience near end of post. You may have noticed a number of newspaper articles/interviews reporting on initial findings of BNC14 spoken #corpus . See end of this post for a list. I had a few questions about what I read and Robbie Love one of the researchers on the project kindly agreed to answer these but I can't report them here. Q1: Is figure of 155 instances per million for marvellous correct? As I found 31.8 from BNC web? Q2: How many tokens make up the approx. 200 recordings that have been used? Q3: There was a tweet saying you are looking for 'native' speakers could you clarify this? Final comments by Robbie: Information about the project, and how to participate, can be found here: http://cass.lancs.ac.uk/?p=1335 Importantly, we’re encouraging speakers to email corpus@cambridge.org to participate in the project. Thanks to Robbie for taking time to answer these questions even if you can't read them here and if you feel like contributing recordings to get in touch with him. Although there is monetary compensation for your efforts what is more attractive is that the corpus will be made available to the public. One final thing is that most of the media reports focused on the American English dominating angle, if you look at COCA for example the same patterns in rise in awesome and decline in marvelous (note single l) can be seen in US English - https://googledrive.com/host/0B7FW2BYaBgeieUlZTDNXT1hzVnM/Awesome_MarvelousUSSpokenEnglish.png Media report list: No longer marvellous... now everything is awesome: How Britons are using more American words because traditional English is in decline [http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2733912/No-longer-marvellous-awesome-Britons-using-American-words-traditional-English-decline.html] From marvellous to awesome: how spoken British English has changed [http://www.theguardian.com/science/shortcuts/2014/aug/26/british-english-words-endangered-awesome-marvellous] Awesome! How American words are changing the way we speak [http://www.express.co.uk/news/uk/503279/Americanisms-changing-the-way-we-speak] ‘Pussy cat’, ‘marvellous’ and ‘cheerio’ – just some of the words that no longer exist in our vocab [http://metro.co.uk/2014/08/25/pussy-cat-marvellous-and-cheerio-just-some-of-the-words-that-no-longer-exist-in-our-vocab-4845616/] British people use more American words than ever due to rise of the digital age [http://www.mirror.co.uk/news/uk-news/british-people-use-more-american-4106418] Cheerio Marvellous... You're No Longer Awesome [http://news.sky.com/story/1324831/cheerio-marvellous-youre-no-longer-awesome] BBC Radio 4 - English language becomes more Americanised (starts at 27:58) [http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b04f85bf] Why marvellous isn't awesome anymore [http://phys.org/news/2014-08-marvellous-isnt-awesome.html] 10 words that are dying out - but 'cheerio' is alive and well in Plymouth, says Argyle fan [http://www.plymouthherald.co.uk/10-words-dying-cheerio-alive-Plymouth-says-Argyle/story-22847155-detail/story.html] Cheerio marvellous: The words disappearing from the English vocabulary [http://www.itv.com/news/2014-08-26/cheerio-marvellous-the-words-disappearing-from-the-english-vocabulary/] Swimming in the deep end of the Spoken BNC2014 media frenzy [http://cass.lancs.ac.uk/?p=1407] Modern men rein in the sexist language: Analysis finds terms like sexy or blonde have disappeared from vocabulary when women are referred to [http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2889427/Men-rein-sexist-language-Analysis-finds-terms-like-sexy-blonde-disappeared-vocabulary-women-referred-to.html] [embed]http://cass.lancs.ac.uk/?p=1335[/embed]
item.excerpt:encoded: #BNC14 media blitz

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: a write up in the #ESRC magazine Society Now, pages 24-25. new info (to me) - in 1990s love collocated with mainly people in the 2010 corpus it is now more material items such as cheese, garden, and clothes eventhough Facebook is mentioned more times than Twitter the meaning of tweet has changed dramatically compared to Facebook related words such as status, comment and wall. http://www.esrc.ac.uk/_images/Society-Now-20-web_tcm8-32429.pdf

item.title: I am following an #iTDi course on ELT Reading materials design.
item.dc:creator: MuraNava
item.content:encoded: I am following an #iTDi course on ELT Reading materials design. Week2 session included use of vocabulary profilers such as #lextutor vocab profile to check whether a text reaches the 95-98 percent coverage of vocab needed to understand it well. An issue that arose is how to handle specialized texts. That is how can we create a vocab profile that will take into account technical/specialised vocabulary. One rough way to do that is first collect the specialized texts you want. Then using #AntWordProfiler [http://www.laurenceanthony.net/antwordprofiler_index.html] open this collection. Next make sure the Include words not in lists(s) checkbox is ticked. Then press Start. Scroll through the result to find the Groups NOT Found In Base Lists results. Copy and paste these into Excel. From Excel just select  the first column (the words column) and copy paste that into a text file, name it appropriately and save it. You can now load this text file into AntWordProfiler in addition to the default lists of the General Service List and the Academic Word List. Finally load up a sample text you want to profile and you will now see any specialized vocabulary being profiled due to the new word list you created previously. Note1: if you are using mac osx mavericks when you paste the word column into a text file, make sure to save the text file as a windows (MS-DOS) text file otherwise AntWordProfiler will put all the words onto one line when loading the text. Though Laurence Anthony  notes simply saving as a UTF-8 should suffice. Note2: the words in your new list won’t be grouped into word families each word will be treated as a word family. Not sure yet best way to group word families automatically.
item.excerpt:encoded: I am following an #iTDi course on ELT Reading materials design.

item.title: The following is related to an #iTDi course on ELT Reading materials design.
item.dc:creator: MuraNava
item.content:encoded: The following is related to an #iTDi course on ELT Reading materials design. A slideshare presentation by Ryota Ito (@i_narrator)[http://www.slideshare.net/gontagogogo/2014graded-readers-slideshare] shows some fascinating differences found in #graded #readers of #Sherlock #Holmes stories that goes beyond simple lexical coverage. Using factor analysis he reports 3 factors that differentiate original readers of Sherlock Holmes from their graded reader equivalents. The three factors are 1. keywords and explicitness 2. century (19C vs 20C) 4. subjectivity The first screen shot shows keywords in Original Readers (OR) and Graded Readers (GR): [Screenshot1- http://media.englishup.me/keyword.png] In GR there is an increase in explicitness (see next screenshot), increase in colloquialisms and reduction in post-modifiers (e.g. prepositional phrases, relative clauses). The following is a screenshot illustrating explicitness i.e. the graded readers are re-written to explicitly indicate who is talking: [Screenshot2 - http://media.englishup.me/explicitness.png] The next screenshot shows first person rewrites of third person language: [Screenshot3 - http://media.englishup.me/subjectivity1.png] And the following is again a subjective factor, this time maybe can be described as conversational/spoken language rewrite with the use of But: [Screenshot4 - http://media.englishup.me/subjectivity2.png] This was a great slide presentation for me with regard to graded readers as I was only previously thinking about token issues rather than wider text issues such as explicitness, first person/third person, subjective/objective. All errors and omissions mine and not Ryota Ito's.
item.excerpt:encoded: The following is related to an #iTDi course on ELT Reading materials design.

item.dc:creator: MuraNava
item.content:encoded: Nice use of looking at concordances to investigate the use of besides which starts a sentence by Julie Moore. There is a related post here http://taiwanonymous.blogspot.fr/2008/08/usage-of-sentence-initial-besides-in.html which finds that "besides is adding another argument against something". That argument could be less important or more or most as Julie's post suggests. h/t Carol Goodey  [embed]http://lexicoblog.blogspot.ca/2014/10/besides-dodgy-discourse-marker.html[/embed]

item.title: Great news!
item.dc:creator: MuraNava
item.content:encoded: Great news! The ESRC Centre for Corpus Approaches to Social Science in association with the ESRC Festival of Social Sciences will be livestreaming their Language Matters: Communication, Culture, and Society event next Tuesday November 4. I copy/paste some details below from a #corpusmooc email: ------------------ From 1730 - 1900 GMT on 4 November, the ESRC Centre for Corpus Approaches to Social Science is hosting a live event in association with the ESRC Festival of Social Sciences and in tangent with our popular FutureLearn course. We would be thrilled if you could ‘tune in’ and collaborate with us to create yet another innovative, educational event, entitled “Language Matters: Communication, Culture, and Society”. This evening is a mini-series of four informal talks showcasing the impact of language on society. These are presented by some of your favourite course contributors (including the lead educator, Tony McEnery) and their talks draw upon the most popular themes in the course:     - What can corpora tell us about learning a foreign language? (with Vaclav Brezina)     - A ‘battle’, a ‘journey’, or none of these? Metaphors for cancer (with Elena Semino)     - Wolves in the wires: online abuse from people to press (with Claire Hardaker)     - Words 'yesterday and today' (with Tony McEnery) There are two ways to virtually attend. First, via Google Hangout if you have a Google account. Sign up at https://plus.google.com/events/ca15afbicmmeiu6d25pn1qbverg and then log in from 17:15 GMT  on 4 November to greet your fellow participants. If you don’t have a Google account, you can watch us on YouTube at Language Matters: Communication, Culture, and Society (#corpusMOOC) with no registration. We’ll be taking questions from the Google Hangout and from the #corpusMOOC hashtag on Twitter (particularly for those viewing on YouTube) and mixing these in with questions from our live audience. You’ll be able to have the sort of immediate interaction that has made the course such a pleasure for facilitators, mentors, and participants alike. ------------------- [embed]https://plus.google.com/events/ca15afbicmmeiu6d25pn1qbverg[/embed]

item.title: Today's livestream of #ESRC #CASS #esrcfestival event is now available on youtube.
item.dc:creator: MuraNava
item.content:encoded: Today's livestream of #ESRC #CASS #esrcfestival event is now available on youtube. Some great info here and the following are my quick notes after watching the recordings: In Vaclav Brezina's talk we learn that the learner #corpus he has built with colleagues called the Trinity Lancaster Spoken Learner Corpus will be publically available sometime in 2017. Woot :) The corpus includes English learners aged from 8 to 72, totalling some 300 people. One of the initial findings is that successful learners use backchannelling as such as oh, ah, mm more than less successful learners as well as asking questions at the right time. The visualisation tool the corpus team is developing looks very neat as well. Claire Hardaker and Elena Semino talks were very interesting . One thing noticeable about Claire Hardaker's talk was how extreme behavior related to gender was clearly contextualised using the examples of the messages pushed by the advertising industry. However extreme political behaviour was not contextualised in a parallel way but in fact lumped in with extreme gender related behaviour. The last talk by Claire Dembry and Robbie Love (introduced by Tony McEnery) dealt with the BNC14 spoken corpus. You can find a collection of newspaper reports at the end of this post https://plus.google.com/104940199413423400545/posts/1HGHyCeHMt8 that report most of the things they talk about. Some new info includes changes in collocates with woman over 20 years, seems that there is less collocates related to physical appearance and sexualised terms. And tea, cake seems as popular as 20 yrs ago. The team reported that after the initial general call for recordings they are looking for teens and younger, and older participants from Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland. A great event many thanks to all involved. [embed]https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hF_fl95tiSk#t=5833[/embed]
item.excerpt:encoded: Today's livestream of #ESRC #CASS #esrcfestival event is now available on youtube.
