Opportunity to contribute to a Cambridge English corpus of academic English. Open to native and non-native speakers. Link goes to the Cambridge English Page on FB.
[embed]https://www.facebook.com/CambridgeEnglish/posts/10153837576840121[/embed]
item.excerpt:encoded: Opportunity to contribute to a Cambridge English corpus of academic English.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: i have sent my obligatory email asking about open access to public :)
Good good, Mura Nava :)
had a reply from them saying it will be available for "researchers" and procedure to apply as such should be straightforward so some "open" light there :)

item.title: What code to use to remove all quoted texts from a corpus / or a long single text?
item.dc:creator: LALAcademy
item.content:encoded: What code to use to remove all quoted texts from a corpus / or a long single text? Anyone knows any line of code in any programming language that helps to omit quoted texts marked by quotations marks from a long text or a corpus of long texts? Will be really grateful for the help!
item.excerpt:encoded: What code to use to remove all quoted texts from a corpus / or a long single text?

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: hi the most obvious is to use regular expressions e.g. http://www.rexegg.com/regex-lookarounds.html http://www.metaltoad.com/blog/regex-quoted-string-escapable-quotes or you can do this with a text editor that does regex e.g. Notepadd++ does that help at all?

Thanks a lot for your comment; I'll give it a go. I'm trying to delete all quoted texts from a written learner corpus I collected as the quoted texts are not theirs, so the analysis results will be skewed!!
do post back here with any findings : )
Keep a copy of your original corpus. You might want to do some research on what was quoted, perhaps who knows?, and it would definitely be useful. :)
good advice Valentini : )
sure, thanks
Valentini Mellas yes I do keep a copy of the original file. I have to convert the copied files to .txt as input for Python so cannot use the original .doc texts; but thanks for the comment

Ahm, LAL Academy, if you have the corpus as DOC then all you have to do is save it in .txt using Notepad++ (as Mura Nava mentioned) and don't forget about encoding (in case you are dealing with languages like Greek that requires Unicode). If you keep the original DOCs though you still have your corpus ;) ... I think that the conversion of your raw texts (DOCs) into TXT without altering will take only a few moments. You can even use the Zilla batch converter to make your life even easier: http://www.pdfzilla.com/zilla_word_to_text_converter.html

That's right Valentini, another way is to click 'save as' in Word, choose Text Encoded, choose UTF-8 (for Linux), choose CR/LF for End line with, click ok and gives you a plain .txt format; hope this comes handy for others some times!
update: Pete Bleackley gave me a line of code in Python that might come handy for others as well: re.sub('''[^"]*''',",document) Thanks to Pete for his prompt response!

Out of curiosity. Have you normalized your documents? i.e. are you sure that all quoted text uses indeed the quotation marks and that the mark is always the same? I am asking because, for example, block quotations do not need the quotation marks. Do you, perhaps, also have quotes within quotes?
Also, is your corpus in Us English or UK English? UK uses single quotes for quotations and double quotes for the quote within a quote scenario, while US English uses the exact opposite. The regex provided by Mr. Bleackley doesn't include the single quotes also...
Sorry if I am being a pest but the issue of quotation marks is a bit more complex than we usually think.

item.title: Does 'bossy' collocate with female nouns (as claimed here http://www.bbc.com/news/blogs-magazine-monitor-26543719 ).
item.dc:creator: ScottThornbury
item.content:encoded: Does 'bossy' collocate with female nouns (as claimed here http://www.bbc.com/news/blogs-magazine-monitor-26543719 ). This is what SketchEngine has to say:
item.excerpt:encoded: Does 'bossy' collocate with female nouns (as claimed here http://www.bbc.com/news/blogs-magazine-monitor-26543719 ).

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: this guy did an analysis using COCA (http://linguisticpulse.com/2014/03/10/some-data-to-support-the-gendered-nature-of-bossy/) and found nearly 3 times used in reference to women and girls compared to men and boys, the BBC article quotes a figure of 4 times (no source) his last paragraph is eminently sensible i.e. no ban of the word but discussion on its use is your sketchengine result based on the ententen web corpus? did you try looking at collocates of pushy (as mentioned in BBC article)?
It was the Cambridge International Corpus (is that the ententen?) I'll post the results of 'pushy' in a separate window.
ah right no the ententen is a web crawled corpus not as balanced as cic but much bigger (i think!)

Serious question and not a challenge to Scott at all. Is it OK to share/publish CUP corpus results? I signed a non-disclosure agreement, so assumed even snippets and insights gained from CIC would be off limits. Any thoughts? Scott, is CIC in Sketch publically?
Diane Nicholls interesting question diane, Sketch Engine on terms page say provide data as is, yet the results page scott posted has been processed by sketchengine?

CIC uses Sketch Engine but I didn't think it was publicly available. CUP authors and researchers have access to it but are bound by non-disclosure. I was wondering whether a portion of CIC had been made public. If not, what exactly non-disclosure restricts users to.

item.title: What 'pushy' modifies (according to Cambridge International Corpus)
item.dc:creator: ScottThornbury
item.content:encoded: What 'pushy' modifies (according to Cambridge International Corpus)
item.excerpt:encoded: What 'pushy' modifies (according to Cambridge International Corpus)

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: what are the contexts for pushy nag? do they all refer to women?
someone (Alon Lischinsky ‏@alischinsky) used google books to look at nouns following bossy http://bit.ly/1i7ZAjL

http://www.newrepublic.com/article/117076/sheryl-sandbergs-ban-bossy-campaign-right-about-one-thing another article which refs a Sketch Engine search using a 13 billion corpus, but no name is given for this corpus. only ref i could find to a 13 bill corpus and sketchengine is to a usenet corpus (http://wacky.sslmit.unibo.it/lib/exe/fetch.php?media=papers:wacky_2008.pdf) which i think means this one http://www.psych.ualberta.ca/~westburylab/downloads/usenetcorpus.download.html which says it is a 7 billion corpus.
a linguist brings the smackdown on naive notions of text analysis http://linguisticpulse.com/2014/03/28/no-really-bossy-is-gendered/

item.title: Thanks for inviting me to join, I'm very ignorant about corpus linguistics so really looking forward to learning...
item.dc:creator: GabrielleJones
item.content:encoded: Thanks for inviting me to join, I'm very ignorant about corpus linguistics so really looking forward to learning more!
item.excerpt:encoded: Thanks for inviting me to join, I'm very ignorant about corpus linguistics so really looking forward to learning...

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
hi Gabrielle Jones welcome great to see u here
i am sure there will be a forum for the #corpusmooc course itself, hoping that this community can be a hub for questions focused on language learning and teaching
don't hesitate to post any questions, thoughts, links
ta mura

I think the best introduction to the discipline is From Corpus to Classroom http://books.google.co.jp/books?id=O3k0tWLp5LYC  by O'Keeffe, McCarthy and Carter. I found this is a very accesable text for those who do langauge teaching. But of course feel free to ask questions.

thanks Peter Parise  that's a great recommendation with the added bonus that one can find a pdf of it to trial ;) at the risk of repeating myself (though seems G+ has lost post to second text!) i would highly recommend the following 2 texts by Frankenberg Garcia: Integrating corpora with everyday language teaching - http://www.academia.edu/3368339/Integrating_corpora_with_everyday_language_teaching Raising teachers' awareness of corpora - https://drive.google.com/file/d/0B7FW2BYaBgeiNy1vOWIyLXdNSTA/edit?usp=sharing as a side note seems G+ categories are unstable so if you want to see all posts so far make sure to go through allposts category!

item.title: Anybody here aware of an existing, preferably open source, corpus of art critiques?
item.dc:creator: MATT
item.content:encoded: Anybody here aware of an existing, preferably open source, corpus of art critiques? I would like to identify frequently occurring multi-word strings for teaching.
item.excerpt:encoded: Anybody here aware of an existing, preferably open source, corpus of art critiques?

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: i am sure there is but i also assume it will be hard to find : ) hence have you considered compiling your own corpus of art critiques?
Yes, that is probably the route I'll take. It's for use with pre-university students so I might see if it is possible to filter BAWE to anything near such a corpus first.
Mura Nava Yes, I expect I'll end up doing that. Will have a go at filtering BAWE first.
the corpus building facility in the BYU-COCA corpus set might be worth exploring as well?
Mura Nava Good idea! Thanks!
No worries Matt, be interested in your progress on this 😉

item.title: Hi everyone
item.dc:creator: roxanaprunache
item.content:encoded:
Hi everyone,
I am currently trying to write a PhD Proposal on "Translating False Friends from/into French, English and Romanian."
I am struggling to build a corpus that could cover all these language pairs, as well as the "false friends" issue.
Unfortunately, the Romanian language is not as commun as the English one when it comes to Corpus Linguistics (especially for the Romanian-French pair).
So I would like to ask for your help on this matter. Every hint/opinion/link would be highly appreciated.
PS: Could you also tell me if there are any "Trilingual concordancers" compatible with IOS? I am having some problems with installing Panaconc on my MAC (I've found a free version but I think it is not working).
Thanks a lot.
Looking forward for your replies,
Roxana
item.excerpt:encoded: Hi everyone

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: I'm sure somebody will help here but if nobody can, I sometimes find a message on Twitter with #corpuslinguistics can help. Best of luck!

I am sure, you can find some one for solving your problem. You can visit my web site. i wrote down articleAbout #corpuslinguistics http://notesgoogle.com/what-is-corpus-linguistics-and-stages-in-building-corpus/ . you will know how to do develop corpus.

Hi Roxana do you have to build a corpus for your proposal? there are a few Romanian corpora from translated documents on the net though not sure if these would suit your project (e.g. http://opus.lingfil.uu.se/) for IOS did you mean OSX? as i think it would be difficult to find concordancers for mobile operating systems good luck!
hi Duncan no I think she means words in one language which look similar in another but don't mean the same thing, also called false cognates
Sorry for the confusion. I have with drawn my comment. The deception angle was one I have been researching lately using CL. Thanks for the clarification.
no worries Duncan, that sounds interesting do you have any further info on that?

Hi all,
Is there an easy way of downloading thousands of newspapers from LexisNexis using a certain software? Because it takes time and effort to download individual articles. Thanks in advance
item.excerpt:encoded: Hi all

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: not possible apparently under terms of API - http://stackoverflow.com/questions/19138763/how-to-take-articles-from-lexisnexis-with-script guess they must have a service for batch download that you pay for?

i think this study used lexis-nexis and they mention on page 14 of downloading 200 texts at a time https://www.academia.edu/407464/Gabrielatos_C._2007_._Selecting_query_terms_to_build_a_specialised_corpus_from_a_restricted-access_database._ICAME_Journal_31_5-43 h/t #corpusmooc

item.title: Hi all
item.dc:creator: DhiaaKareem
item.content:encoded:
Hi all,
I was trying to obtain a keyword list by comparing a corpus I have (around 8650 words) with Brown corpus as a reference corpus using Wordsmith 6.0 but I got this notice "text doesn't seem to be valid file for WordList" Please, could you help in this matter.
Thanks in advance
item.excerpt:encoded: Hi all

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: hi Dhiaa I don't use Wordsmith but I guess it is do with the format Wordsmith accepts for files. Is the problem with your corpus or with Brown corpus? Have you checked the encoding for your corpus? To check encoding you can use EncodeAnt.

Hi Mura,
I have checked the same sets of corpora in AntConc and they both work.
have u checked Worsmith help files e.g. http://lexically.net/downloads/version7/HTML/index.html?invalid_wordlist_file_error.htm
Thanks a lot, Mura. It seems a problem of compatibility. I will try to examine the extensions. The link you sent is very helpful.
great good luck

item.title: Hi all
item.dc:creator: DhiaaKareem
item.content:encoded:
Hi all,
I want to copy the concordances lines from Wordsmith software into excel but it doesn't keep the wordsmith concordances format. Is there an easy way of doing it and I will be grateful.
Best,
item.excerpt:encoded: Hi all

item.title: Hi all
item.dc:creator: DhiaaKareem
item.content:encoded:
Hi all,
I just built my corpus (newspapers collection) and I wonder what is meant corpus cleaning.
item.excerpt:encoded: Hi all

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
corpus cleaning generally means removing what maybe irrelevant things in your corpus;
many advise to make copies so that your original corpus is kept should you want to revert to items you previously deleted

Thank you so much Mura. This is what I am doing write now for instance deleting the following from the articles:
BYLINE: A.E. CULLISON; Journal of Commerce Staff
SECTION: FRONT, Pg. 3A
LENGTH: 263 words
DATELINE: TOKYO LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996
LANGUAGE: ENGLISH
EDITOR-NOTE
but I noticed that takes a very long time. Is there anyway that I can go around it or just I have to do it.

If you are working on text files, the search and replace function in a text editor is one way. The best one out there is Notepad++. Ideally this is for software developers. https://notepad-plus-plus.org/ Laurence Anthony has a batch search and replace tool to filter out certain text from your corpus. This enables you to edit all of your files as once. laurenceanthony.net - Laurence Anthony's SarAnt Check it out. ლ(╹◡╹ლ) I hope this helps.
Thanks you so much Peter. I checked them and I could not manage to do it.
you may need to read up a bit on regular expressions to help you define the items you want to delete

Dhiaa Kareem It does take a little time to get used to. But I realized something, rather than delete that information why not use brackets to hide them in your analysis.
<LENGTH: 263 words>
Some corpus programs can be set to ignore words between "<" and ">" I know Laurence Anthony's AntConc software can do this.
thing with Antconc and tags is that although you can hide tags they are still counted by the program no?
Good question. I checked on a tagged corpus and no it doesn't count them. It depends on the "global settings" for the program.

Peter Parise and @ Mura Thank you for your kind help. to use brackets to hide the irrelevant texts will more difficult than deleting them at them same time. I am not experienced with CL but do you think that leaving the following texts and similar ones will effect the results
BYLINE: A.E. CULLISON; Journal of Commerce Staff
SECTION: FRONT, Pg. 3A
LENGTH: 263 words
DATELINE: TOKYO LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996
LANGUAGE: ENGLISH
EDITOR-NOTE
If you do leave them it would impact the results. I think the easiest thing to do is use a text editor in Windows and use "Search and replace" https://youtu.be/pgWIoeX5Vh8
If you do leave them it would impact the results. I think the easiest thing to do is use a text editor in Windows and use "Search and replace" https://youtu.be/pgWIoeX5Vh8
If you do leave them it would impact the results. I think the easiest thing to do is use a text editor in Windows and use "Search and replace" https://youtu.be/pgWIoeX5Vh8
